5_CD ,_, 129_CD REPLACEMENT_NNP OF_NNP PLANT_NNP PROTEINS_NNP BY_NNP ANIMAL_NNP PROTEINS_NNP IN_NNP THE_NNP RATIONS_NNP OF_NNP BREEDING_NNP BULLS_NNP AND_CC ITS_NNP EFFECT_NNP ON_NNP SEMEN_NNP PRODUCTION_NNP By_IN S._NNP S._NNP PRABHU_NNP ,_, S._NNP GUHA_NNP and_CC P._NNP BHATTACHARYA_NNP ,_, Animal_NNP Genetics_NNP Section_NNP ,_, Indian_JJ Veterinary_NNP Research_NNP Institute_NNP ,_, Izatnagar_NNP (_( Received_VBN for_IN publication_NN on_IN 8_CD April_NNP 1953_CD )_) LITTLE_NNP information_NN is_VBZ available_JJ on_IN the_DT effect_NN of_IN specific_JJ nutritional_JJ factors_NNS upon_IN semen_NNS production_NN ._.
Jones_NNP ,_, Haag_NNP and_CC Dougherty_NNP [_NNP 1942_CD ]_NN showed_VBD that_IN rations_NNS satisfactory_VBP for_IN normal_JJ growth_NN up_IN to_TO three_CD years_NNS of_IN age_NN are_VBP adequate_JJ for_IN normal_JJ reproductive_JJ function_NN ._.
Branton_NNP ,_, Bratton_NNP and_CC Salisbury_NNP [_NNP 1942_CD ]_NNP fed_VBD bulls_NNS used_VBN for_IN artificial_JJ insemination_NN with_IN 100_CD ,_, 120_CD and_CC 140_CD per_IN cent_NN levels_NNS of_IN T._NNP D._NNP N._NNP of_IN Morrison_NNP dry_JJ cow_NN requirement_NN and_CC observed_VBD that_IN neither_CC the_DT quantity_NN and_CC quality_NN of_IN semen_NNS produced_VBN nor_CC the_DT fertility_NN of_IN the_DT bulls_NNS was_VBD related_VBN to_TO the_DT digestible_JJ nutrient_JJ intake_NN within_IN the_DT limits_NNS studied_VBN ._.
They_PRP also_RB observed_VBD that_IN concentrate_NN mixtures_NNS containing_VBG 12_CD per_IN cent_NN ,_, 16_CD per_IN cent_NN and_CC 20_CD per_IN cent_NN total_JJ protein_NN did_VBD not_RB significantly_RB affect_VBP the_DT fertility_NN of_IN bulls_NNS ._.
On_IN the_DT basis_NN of_IN their_PRP$ findings_NNS ,_, they_PRP have_VBP suggested_VBN a_DT feeding_NN schedule_NN for_IN bulls_NNS in_IN active_JJ service_NN ._.
Reid_NNP ,_, Ward_NNP and_CC Salisbury_NNP [_NNP 1948_CD ]_NNP ,_, who_WP tried_VBD simple_JJ and_CC complex_JJ concentrate_NN mixtures_NNS on_IN young_JJ breeding_NN bulls_NNS ,_, observed_VBD that_IN good_JJ quality_NN semen_NNS of_IN similar_JJ character_NN resulted_VBD from_IN the_DT ingestion_NN of_IN both_DT diets_NNS ,_, when_WRB given_VBN at_IN the_DT average_JJ rate_NN of_IN 1.18_CD lb_NN ._.
digestible_JJ nutrients_NNS per_IN 100_CD lb_NN ._.
body_NN weight_VBD daily_RB ._.
Bulls_NNP given_VBN complex_JJ mixture_NN yielded_VBN slightly_RB larger_JJR ejaculates_NNS ,_, containing_VBG more_JJR spermatozoa_JJ per_IN ejaculate_NN and_CC fewer_JJR abnormal_NN spermatozoa_NN than_IN those_DT fed_VBN on_IN simple_JJ mixture_NN ._.
The_DT decrease_NN in_IN pH_NN following_VBG incubation_NN of_IN ejaculated_JJ semen_NNS was_VBD greater_JJR in_IN latter_JJR group_NN than_IN in_IN the_DT former_JJ ._.
Regardless_RB of_IN the_DT diet_JJ fed_VBD the_DT concentration_NN of_IN spermatozoa_NN in_IN semen_NNS ,_, the_DT initial_JJ motility_NN ,_, the_DT degree_NN of_IN livabili-_JJ ty_NN ,_, the_DT size_NN of_IN spermatozoa_NN ,_, the_DT quantity_NN of_IN total_JJ reducing_NN substances_NNS ,_, reducing_VBG sub-_JJ stances_NNS in_IN oxidised_JJ state_NN ,_, potential_JJ reducing_NN capacity_NN ,_, ascorbic_JJ acid_NN and_CC the_DT initial_JJ pH_NN ._.
of_IN the_DT semen_NNS were_VBD similar_JJ ._.
A_DT number_NN of_IN Russian_JJ workers_NNS also_RB have_VBP stressed_VBN the_DT value_NN of_IN proper_JJ feeding_NN in_IN increasing_VBG sperm_JJ production_NN [_NNP Snironov-Ugrjumov_NNP ,_, 1937_CD ;_: Pankhevic_NNP ,_, 1930_CD ;_: Ovsjannikov_NNP ,_, 1939_CD ]_NN ._.
According_VBG to_TO their_PRP$ findings_NNS ,_, the_DT animal_JJ pro-_JJ teins_NNS contained_VBN in_IN blood-meal_NN and_CC skim_NN milk_NN caused_VBN significant_JJ improvement_NN in_IN semen_NNS production_NN when_WRB fed_NN to_TO breeding_VBG bulls_NNS ._.
Branton_NNP ,_, Bratton_NNP and_CC Salisbury_NNP [_NNP 1949_CD ]_NNP ,_, who_WP tried_VBD one_CD animal_NN protein_NN (_( skim_JJ milk_NN powder_NN )_) and_CC two_CD vegetable_JJ proteins_NNS (_( corn_NN gluten_NNS feed_VBP and_CC soyabean_JJ oil_NN meal_NN )_) in_IN an_DT experiment_NN conducted_VBN on_IN 18_CD bulls_NNS em-_JJ ploying_VBG a_DT double_JJ cross_NN over_IN design_NN and_CC a_DT 120_CD days_NNS period_NN ,_, could_MD get_VB no_DT confirmation_NN of_IN these_DT results_NNS ._.
They_PRP found_VBD that_IN the_DT three_CD protein_NN supplements_NNS were_VBD approximately_RB equal_JJ in_IN value_NN ._.
In_IN India_NNP ,_, the_DT necessity_NN for_IN meeting_VBG the_DT overall_JJ deficit_NN in_IN concentrates_NNS ,_, rendered_VBN acute_NN by_IN the_DT partition_NN of_IN the_DT country_NN ,_, through_IN use_NN of_IN suitable_JJ substitutes_NNS has_VBZ become_VBN urgent_JJ ._.
An_DT attempt_NN has_VBZ been_VBN made_VBN by_IN the_DT authors_NNS to_TO study_VB the_DT possibility_NN of_IN 175_CD 5_CD AR/53_NNP 176_CD REPLACEMENT_NNP OF_NNP PLANT_NNP PROTEINS_NNP IN_NNP THE_NNP RATIONS_NNP [_NNP Vol_NNP ._.
XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, replacing_VBG part_NN of_IN the_DT vegetable_JJ proteins_NNS by_IN animal_JJ protein_NN ,_, like_IN blood-meal_NN (_( skim_JJ milk_NN powder_NN was_VBD out_IN of_IN question_NN ,_, as_IN it_PRP is_VBZ needed_VBN urgently_RB to_TO meet_VB the_DT shortage_NN for_IN human_JJ consumption_NN )_) without_IN impairing_VBG the_DT reproductive_JJ efficiency_NN of_IN artificial_JJ insemination_NN bulls_NNS ._.
EXPERIMENTAL_JJ Eight_NNP Kumaon-Hill_NNP bulls_NNS ranging_VBG in_IN weight_NN from_IN 276_CD to_TO 528_CD lb_NN ._.
were_VBD divided_VBN at_IN random_NN into_IN two_CD lots_NNS of_IN four_CD each_DT ._.
Animals_NNS in_IN the_DT first_JJ group_NN were_VBD fed_VBN ration_NN consisting_VBG of_IN a_DT concentrate_NN mixture_NN made_VBD up_RP as_IN follows_VBZ :_: Crushed_JJ oats_NNS 150_CD parts_NNS by_IN weight_NN Crushed_NNP maize_VBD 150_CD September_NNP ,_, 1953_CD ]_NN S.S_NNP PRABHU_NNP ,_, S._NNP GUHA_NNP AND_NNP P._NNP BHATTACHARAY_NNP 177_CD The_DT quantity_NN of_IN bhusa_NN fed_VBN to_TO bulls_NNS 1_CD ,_, 2_CD and_CC 8_CD was_VBD subsequently_RB raised_VBN to_TO four_CD pounds_NNS ,_, as_IN it_PRP was_VBD observed_VBN that_IN three_CD pounds_NNS allowance_NN was_VBD insufficient_JJ ._.
The_DT experiment_NN was_VBD started_VBN on_IN 29_CD June_NNP ,_, 1949_CD and_CC concluded_VBD on_IN 9_CD November_NNP ,_, 1949_CD ._.
Due_JJ to_TO the_DT non-availability_NN of_IN wheat_NN bran_NN ,_, it_PRP had_VBD to_TO be_VB excluded_VBN from_IN the_DT mixture_NN from_IN 31_CD July_NNP ,_, 1949_CD ._.
The_DT rations_NNS were_VBD weighed_VBN as_IN per_IN schedule_NN drawn_VBN up_RP and_CC fed_VB individually_RB to_TO the_DT animals_NNS ._.
The_DT blood-meal_NN was_VBD added_VBN prior_RB to_TO feeding_VBG ._.
Blood-meal_NNP was_VBD increased_VBN slowly_RB and_CC brought_VBD up_RB to_TO the_DT desired_VBN level_NN to_TO enable_VB the_DT animals_NNS to_TO get_VB used_VBN to_TO it_PRP ._.
Within_IN 4_CD to_TO 8_CD days_NNS all_DT were_VBD readily_RB taking_VBG blood-meal_JJ mixed_JJ in_IN the_DT concentrates_NNS ._.
Semen_NNP was_VBD collected_VBN at_IN weekly_JJ intervals_NNS from_IN all_PDT the_DT bulls_NNS ,_, and_CC on_IN each_DT day_NN of_IN collection_NN two_CD ejaculates_NNS were_VBD taken_VBN and_CC completely_RB analysed_VBN with_IN regard_NN to_TO colour_VB and_CC consistency_VB ,_, volume_NN ,_, initial_JJ motility_NN ,_, sperm_JJ density_NN ,_, percentage_NN of_IN abnor-_JJ mal_JJ sperm_NN and_CC initial_JJ pH_NN ._.
In_IN addition_NN ,_, reaction_NN time_NN for_IN each_DT ejaculate_NN and_CC records_NNS of_IN daily_JJ body_NN weight_NN of_IN the_DT animals_NNS were_VBD maintained_VBN ._.
RESULTS_NNP In_IN Table_NNP II_NNP are_VBP brought_VBN out_RP the_DT averages_NNS of_IN the_DT various_JJ semen_NNS characteristics_NNS ,_, observed_VBN in_IN the_DT two_CD ejaculates_NNS of_IN the_DT control_NN and_CC blood-meal_JJ fed_NN animals_NNS ._.
In_IN addition_NN the_DT averages_NNS of_IN the_DT reaction_NN time_NN ,_, body_NN weights_NNS ,_, rates_NNS of_IN gain_NN and_CC rates_NNS of_IN change_NN in_IN rates_NNS of_IN gain_NN of_IN the_DT different_JJ bulls_NNS are_VBP also_RB given_VBN in_IN the_DT same_JJ table_NN ._.
The_DT figures_NNS given_VBN in_IN columns_NN 13_CD ,_, 14_CD and_CC 15_CD of_IN the_DT table_NN are_VBP respectively_RB the_DT values_NNS of_IN co-efficients_NNS A_NNP ,_, B_NNP and_CC C_NNP obtained_VBN by_IN fitting_VBG orthogonal_JJ polynomials_NNS as_IN described_VBN by_IN Fisher_NNP [_NN 1943_CD ]_NN to_TO the_DT daily_JJ live-weight_JJ data_NNS ._.
The_DT co-efficients_NNS give_VBP respectively_RB (_( i_NN )_) average_NN weight_NN ,_, (_( ii_NN )_) average_NN gain_NN in_IN weight_NN and_CC (_( iii_NN )_) average_NN rate_NN of_IN change_NN in_IN gain_NN of_IN weight_NN ._.
For_IN analysing_VBG the_DT data_NN on_IN semen_NNS characteristics_NNS and_CC reaction_NN time_NN ,_, two_CD different_JJ ,_, methods_NNS were_VBD adopted_VBN ._.
In_IN the_DT first_JJ method_NN ,_, the_DT figures_NNS under_IN each_DT criterion_NN for_IN the_DT different_JJ bulls_NNS in_IN the_DT two_CD groups_NNS were_VBD separately_RB averaged_VBN out_RP and_CC the_DT averages_NNS so_RB obtained_VBD used_VBN in_IN conducting_VBG a_DT straight-forward_JJ analysis_NN of_IN variance_NN ._.
The_DT variance_NN due_JJ to_TO treatment_NN differences_NNS were_VBD tested_VBN using_VBG the_DT 'between_JJ bulls_NNS within_IN feeds_NNS '_POS variance_NN as_IN the_DT error_NN ._.
The_DT results_NNS are_VBP given_VBN in_IN Table_NNP III_NNP ._.
In_IN none_NN of_IN the_DT criteria_NNS were_VBD the_DT treatment_NN differences_NNS found_VBD to_TO be_VB significant_JJ ._.
This_DT method_NN at_IN best_RBS provides_VBZ a_DT rough_JJ and_CC ready_JJ way_NN of_IN testing_VBG overall_JJ group_NN differences_NNS ._.
Besides_IN ,_, the_DT use_NN of_IN averages_NNS smooths_NNS out_RP random_JJ variation_NN between_IN collections_NNS giving_VBG more_RBR stable_JJ figures_NNS for_IN carrying_VBG out_RP the_DT analysis_NN ._.
The_DT analysis_NN ,_, however_RB ,_, does_VBZ not_RB take_VB into_IN account_NN the_DT possible_JJ effect_NN of_IN the_DT time_NN factor_NN on_IN semen_NNS production_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN ._.
In_IN the_DT present_JJ experiment_NN ,_, a_DT certain_JJ amount_NN of_IN seasonal_JJ effect_NN on_IN the_DT results_NNS might_MD reasonably_RB be_VB expected_VBN as_IN the_DT experiment_NN had_VBD lasted_VBN for_IN over_IN four_CD months178_JJ REPLACEMENT_NNP OF_NNP PLANT_NNP PROTEINS_NNP IN_NNP THE_NNP RATIONS_NNP [_NNP Vol_NNP ._.

XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, In_IN the_DT treatment_NN of_IN the_DT data_NNS pertaining_NN to_TO attributes_NNS of_IN semen_NNS quality_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN ,_, the_DT adjustment_NN made_VBD was_VBD for_IN the_DT intial_JJ quality_NN of_IN the_DT semen_NNS for_IN each_DT attribute_NN ._.
In_IN case_NN of_IN reaction_NN time_NN ,_, adjustment_NN was_VBD made_VBN for_IN the_DT initial_JJ reaction_NN time_NN ._.
The_DT initial_JJ semen_NNS quality_NN was_VBD obtained_VBN by_IN averaging_VBG each_DT of_IN the_DT attributes_NNS falling_VBG within_IN the_DT summer_NN month_NN ._.
The_DT total_JJ number_NN of_IN observations_NNS used_VBN for_IN striking_VBG the_DT averages_NNS were_VBD four_CD in_IN all_PDT the_DT first_JJ three_CD weeks_NNS of_IN experimentation_NN ._.
In_IN the_DT like_JJ manner_NN ,_, four_CD observations_NNS per_IN attribute_NN falling_VBG within_IN the_DT last_JJ three_CD weeks_NNS of_IN the_DT experiment_NN were_VBD utilised_VBN for_IN getting_VBG the_DT averages_NNS of_IN the_DT final_JJ figures_NNS which_WDT were_VBD adjusted_VBN with_IN the_DT inital_JJ figures_NNS in_IN the_DT analysis_NN of_IN co-variance_NN ._.
Thus_RB ,_, not_RB only_RB more_RBR stable_JJ observations_NNS within_IN the_DT two_CD seasons_NNS ,_, viz_NN ._.
summer_NN and_CC autumn_NN ,_, were_VBD obtained_VBN ,_, but_CC ,_, due_JJ to_TO the_DT use_NN of_IN like_IN number_NN of_IN observations_NNS in_IN the_DT two_CD averages_NNS ,_, the_DT averages_NNS also_RB were_VBD brought_VBN on_IN to_TO a_DT comparable_JJ basis_NN ._.
The_DT results_NNS are_VBP summarised_VBN in_IN Table_NNP IV_NNP (_( a_DT )_) and_CC (_( b_NN )_) ._.
From_IN a_DT study_NN of_IN Tables_NNP II_NNP ,_, III_NNP and_CC IV_NNP (_( a_DT )_) and_CC (_( b_NN )_) the_DT following_JJ facts_NNS emerge_VBP :_: Volume_NN ._.
The_DT average_JJ semen_JJ volume_NN was_VBD higher_RBR in_IN the_DT second_JJ than_IN in_IN the_DT first_JJ ejaculate_NN in_IN both_DT groups_NNS ._.
Between_NNP ejaculate_NN difference_NN was_VBD not_RB statistically_RB significant_JJ ._.
The_DT overall_JJ group_NN average_NN for_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ fed_NN group_NN was_VBD 1.59_CD c.c_NN ._.
while_IN it_PRP was_VBD 1.80_CD c.c_NN ._.
for_IN the_DT control_NN group_NN ._.
The_DT difference_NN in_IN the_DT adjusted_JJ overall_JJ group_NN means_VBZ failed_VBN to_TO reach_VB the_DT level_NN of_IN significance_NN ._.
Initial_JJ motility_NN ._.
The_DT average_JJ motility_NN rating_NN was_VBD slightly_RB in_IN favour_NN of_IN the_DT second_JJ ejaculate_NN in_IN case_NN of_IN bulls_NNS in_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ group_NN ;_: while_IN it_PRP was_VBD markedly_RB in_IN favour_NN of_IN the_DT second_JJ ejaculate_NN in_IN the_DT control_NN group_NN ._.
As_IN before_RB ,_, between_IN ejaculate_JJ differences_NNS as_RB well_RB as_IN the_DT adjusted_JJ lot_NN mean_JJ difference_NN ,_, were_VBD not_RB significant_JJ ._.
The_DT actual_JJ mean_NN motility_NN rating_NN for_IN blood-meal_JJ group_NN was_VBD 3.39_CD while_IN it_PRP was_VBD 3.50_CD for_IN the_DT control_NN ._.

The_DT mean_NN was_VBD 983.05_CD millions_NNS per_IN c.c_NN ._.
for_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ group_NN and_CC 874.30_CD millions_NNS per_IN c.c_NN ._.
for_IN the_DT control_NN group_NN ._.

Per_NNP cent_NN abnormal_NN sperms_NNS ._.

The_DT mean_NN for_IN the_DT second_JJ ejaculate_NN was_VBD observed_VBN to_TO be_VB higher_JJR than_IN for_IN the_DT first_JJ in_IN both_DT groups_NNS ,_, the_DT group_NN means_VBZ being_VBG 1,465_CD and_CC 1,577_CD millions_NNS respectively_RB for_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ and_CC control_NN groups_NNS ._.

The_DT difference_NN again_RB was_VBD not_RB statistically_RB significant_JJ ,_, though_IN between_IN ejaculate_NN difference_NN was_VBD highly_RB significant_JJ ._.

XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, Reaction_NNP time_NN ._.
Bulls_NNS in_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ group_NN took_VBD longer_JJR time_NN on_IN an_DT average_NN to_TO give_VB the_DT first_JJ ejaculate_NN than_IN the_DT second_JJ ,_, while_IN opposite_NN was_VBD the_DT case_NN with_IN bulls_NNS in_IN the_DT control_NN group_NN ._.
The_DT between_IN ejaculates_NNS difference_NN ,_, however_RB ,_, was_VBD not_RB statistically_RB significant_JJ ._.
The_DT overall_JJ group_NN average_NN for_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ fed_NN lot_NN was_VBD 80.78_CD seconds_NNS as_IN opposed_VBN to_TO 91.5_CD second_NN for_IN the_DT controls_NNS ._.
The_DT difference_NN between_IN groups_NNS ,_, after_IN adjusting_VBG for_IN initial_JJ observation_NN ,_, was_VBD not_RB statistically_RB significant_JJ for_IN both_DT ejaculates_NNS ._.
Body_NN weight_NN ._.

and_CC bull_NN No_NNP ._.

This_DT in_IN all_DT probability_NN ,_, was_VBD due_JJ to_TO their_PRP$ receiving_NN slightly_RB lesser_JJR amount_NN of_IN starch-equivalent_NN than_IN their_PRP$ actual_JJ requirement_NN ._.

DISCUSSION_NNP AND_NNP CONCLUSION_NNP Mukherjee_NNP and_CC Bhattacharya_NNP [_NNP unpublished_JJ ]_NN who_WP studied_VBD the_DT seasonal_JJ variation_NN in_IN semen_NNS quality_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN of_IN Kumauni_NNP Hill_NNP bulls_VBZ observed_VBD the_DT following_JJ characteristics_NNS in_IN these_DT animals_NNS during_IN the_DT months_NNS of_IN autumn_NN :_: (_( i_NN )_) Reaction_NNP time=73.42_NN seconds_NNS (_( ii_NN )_) Initial_NNP pH=6.25_NN (_( iii_NN )_) Volume=2.28_NNP c.c_NN ._.
(_( iv_NN )_) Initial_NNP motility=3.48_NN (_( v_NN )_) Sperm_NNP density=534.85_NN millions_NNS per_IN c.c_NN ._.
(_( vi_NN )_) Per_NNP cent_NN abnormal_NN sperm=5.57_NN per_IN cent_NN and_CC (_( vii_NN )_) Total_NNP number_NN of_IN sperm_NN in_IN ejaculate=1,284.24_CC million_CD The_DT chief_JJ concern_NN of_IN the_DT person_NN in_IN charge_NN of_IN field_NN artificial_JJ insemination_NN centres_NNS is_VBZ to_TO keep_VB close_JJ watch_NN on_IN the_DT following_JJ attributes_NNS of_IN semen_NNS quality_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN :_: (_( i_NN )_) Volume_NN (_( ii_NN )_) Motility_NN and_CC (_( iii_NN )_) Sperm_NNP concentration_NN ._.
According_VBG to_TO the_DT observations_NNS of_IN the_DT above_NN mentioned_VBD authors_NNS ,_, significant_JJ difference_NN in_IN 'Reaction-time_JJ '_'' was_VBD found_VBN only_RB between_IN bulls_NNS ._.
The_DT differences_NNS in_IN years_NNS and_CC seasons_NNS were_VBD not_RB significant_JJ ._.
Same_NNP was_VBD true_JJ of_IN volume_NN of_IN semen_NNS ._.
Sperm_NNP concentration_NN was_VBD found_VBN to_TO vary_VB not_RB only_RB from_IN bull_NN to_TO bull_VB but_CC also_RB between_IN seasons_NNS ,_, while_IN motility_NN varied_VBN significantly_RB from_IN bull_NN to_TO bull_VB ,_, year_NN to_TO year_NN and_CC between_IN one_CD season_NN and_CC another_DT ._.
The_DT reaction_NN time_NN observed_VBN in_IN the_DT control_NN of_IN our_PRP$ experiment_NN with_IN which_WDT the_DT observations_NNS of_IN Mukherjee_NNP and_CC Bhattacharya_NNP loc_NN ._.
cit_NN ._.
could_MD be_VB com-_JJ pared_VBN ,_, showed_VBD longer_JJR time_NN ._.
The_DT volume_NN of_IN semen_NNS was_VBD found_VBN to_TO be_VB slightly_RB lower_JJR ._.
These_DT differences_NNS could_MD be_VB attributed_VBN largely_RB to_TO the_DT individuality_NN of_IN the_DT bulls_NNS ._.
The_DT sperm_JJ concentration_NN ,_, however_RB ,_, was_VBD decidedly_RB superior_JJ to_TO that_DT got_VBN by_IN Mukherjee_NNP and_CC Bhattacharya_NNP ,_, while_IN the_DT motility_NN rating_NN was_VBD approximately_RB of_IN the_DT same_JJ order_NN ._.
In_IN September_NNP ,_, 1953_CD ]_NNP S._NNP S._NNP PRABHU_NNP ,_, S._NNP GUHA_NNP ,_, AND_NNP P._NNP BHATTACHARYA_NNP 185_CD view_NN of_IN this_DT ,_, it_PRP could_MD be_VB stated_VBN that_IN the_DT quality_NN of_IN the_DT semen_NNS produced_VBN by_IN the_DT bulls_NNS in_IN the_DT control_NN groups_NNS of_IN our_PRP$ experiment_NN was_VBD in_IN no_DT way_NN inferior_RB to_TO the_DT semen_NNS produced_VBN by_IN the_DT normal_JJ individuals_NNS belonging_VBG to_TO this_DT breed_NN ._.
This_DT fact_NN taken_VBN along_IN with_IN our_PRP$ finding_NN showed_VBD that_IN the_DT blood-meal_JJ fed_NN bulls_NNS produced_VBD semen_NNS of_IN about_IN the_DT same_JJ quality_NN as_IN that_DT expected_VBD from_IN a_DT representative_JJ sample_NN of_IN bulls_NNS of_IN the_DT breed_NN given_VBN normal_JJ rations_NNS ._.
Our_PRP$ findings_NNS were_VBD that_IN the_DT crude_NN vegetable_JJ protein_NN in_IN the_DT rations_NNS of_IN artificial_JJ insemination_NN bulls_NNS could_MD be_VB replaced_VBN by_IN animal_JJ products_NNS like_IN blood-meal_NN ,_, to_TO the_DT extent_NN done_VBN in_IN our_PRP$ study_NN ,_, i.e_NN ._.
by_IN 30_CD per_IN cent_NN ,_, without_IN detriment_NN to_TO normal_JJ semen_NNS production_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN ._.
These_DT results_NNS are_VBP not_RB in_IN agreement_NN with_IN the_DT Russian_JJ findings_NNS and_CC bear_VB out_RP the_DT conclusions_NNS drawn_VBN by_IN Branton_NNP ,_, Bratton_NNP and_CC Salisbury_NNP [_NNP 1949_CD ]_NN who_WP used_VBD skim-milk_JJ powder_NN instead_RB of_IN blood-meal_JJ as_IN a_DT source_NN of_IN animal_NN protein_NN supplement_NN in_IN the_DT concentrate_NN mixture_NN ._.
As_IN our_PRP$ study_NN was_VBD carried_VBN out_RP for_IN a_DT limited_JJ period_NN of_IN four_CD months_NNS ,_, no_DT conclusion_NN on_IN long_JJ term_NN aspect_NN of_IN feeding_VBG blood-meal_NN could_MD naturally_RB be_VB drawn_VBN on_IN the_DT basis_NN of_IN the_DT data_NNS presented_VBN ._.
It_PRP has_VBZ however_RB ,_, clearly_RB demonstrated_VBD that_DT ,_, as_IN a_DT short-term_JJ measure_NN of_IN feeding_VBG bulls_NNS ,_, rations_NNS with_IN ._.
30_CD per_IN cent_NN of_IN the_DT crude_NN protein_NN replaced_VBN by_IN blood-meal_NN could_MD be_VB instituted_VBN without_IN materially_RB affecting_VBG semen_NNS production_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN ._.
This_DT should_MD prove_VB of_IN value_NN in_IN a_DT stop-gap_JJ arrangement_NN of_IN feeding_VBG artificial_JJ insemination_NN bulls_NNS during_IN times_NNS of_IN scarcity_NN of_IN good_JJ quality_NN concentrates_NNS ,_, besides_IN helping_VBG release_NN of_IN valuable_JJ concen-_JJ trates_NNS like_IN maize_NN and_CC linseed_VB cake_NN for_IN effective_JJ use_NN in_IN normal_JJ times_NNS ._.
SUMMARY_NNP 1_CD ._.
Data_NNS are_VBP presented_VBN on_IN the_DT effect_NN of_IN replacing_VBG 30_CD per_IN cent_NN of_IN crude_NN proteins_NNS in_IN normal_JJ rations_NNS of_IN Kumauni_NNP Hill_NNP bulls_NNS by_IN blood-meal_NN ,_, for_IN a_DT period_NN of_IN four_CD months_NNS ,_, on_IN semen_NNS production_NN and_CC reaction_NN time_NN ._.
2_CD ._.
Analysis_NN of_IN the_DT data_NN showed_VBD no_DT significant_JJ difference_NN in_IN the_DT various_JJ semen_NNS characteristics_NNS and_CC reaction_NN times_NNS of_IN bulls_NNS fed_VBN on_IN normal_JJ and_CC blood-meal_JJ replaced_JJ rations_NNS ._.

32_CD ,_, 4_CD ,_, 292EFFECT_CD OF_NNP MONTHLY_NNP CUTS_NNP ON_NNP THE_NNP CHEMICAL_NNP COMPOSITION_NNP OF_NNP SOME_NNP INDIGENOUS_NNP GRASSES_NNP OF_IN INDIA_NNP By_IN NARINDAR_NNP NATH_NNP and_CC N._NNP B_NNP DAS_NNP ,_, Indian_JJ Agricultural_NNP Research_NNP Institute_NNP ,_, New_NNP Delhi_NNP (_( Received_VBN for_IN publication_NN on_IN 5_CD January_NNP 1953_CD )_) (_( With_IN two_CD text-figures_NNS )_) THE_DT desirability_NN of_IN studying_VBG the_DT chemical_JJ composition_NN of_IN various_JJ species_NNS of_IN grasses_NNS found_VBN in_IN the_DT country_NN under_IN different_JJ systems_NNS of_IN cutting_VBG was_VBD emphasised_VBN in_IN a_DT previous_JJ publication_NN in_IN which_WDT the_DT effect_NN of_IN growth_NN stage_NN on_IN the_DT chemical_JJ composition_NN of_IN some_DT grasses_NNS was_VBD studied_VBN [_JJ Narindar_NNP Nath_NNP and_CC Das_NNP ,_, 1952_CD ]_NN ._.
In_IN this_DT investigation_NN the_DT effect_NN of_IN monthly_JJ cuts_NNS on_IN the_DT chemical_JJ composition_NN of_IN some_DT species_NNS of_IN grasses_NNS is_VBZ reported_VBN ._.
The_DT object_NN is_VBZ to_TO bring_VB about_RP condition_NN similar_JJ to_TO intermittent_VB grazing_VBG where_WRB plants_NNS are_VBP allowed_VBN alternately_RB a_DT large_JJ period_NN of_IN unchecked_JJ growth_NN followed_VBN by_IN intensive_JJ grazing_NN for_IN a_DT short_JJ period_NN ._.
In_IN other_JJ words_NNS the_DT investigation_NN aims_VBZ at_IN studying_VBG how_WRB the_DT chemical_JJ composition_NN of_IN grasses_NNS varies_NNS with_IN season_NN when_WRB under_IN grazing_VBG with_IN a_DT month_NN 's_POS closure_NN ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ ,_, of_IN course_NN ,_, true_JJ that_IN conditions_NNS are_VBP not_RB exactly_RB identical_JJ with_IN actual_JJ grazing_NN which_WDT is_VBZ not_RB so_RB uniform_JJ ._.
In_IN grazing_VBG the_DT animals_NNS sort_VBP out_RP certain_JJ plants_NNS and_CC even_RB certain_JJ parts_NNS of_IN the_DT plants_NNS and_CC eat_VB them_PRP first_RB pre-_NN ferably_RB leaving_VBG the_DT stemy_JJ portion_NN while_IN some_DT of_IN the_DT plants_NNS are_VBP trampled_VBN over_IN during_IN grazing_NN ._.
Moreover_RB ,_, the_DT manuring_VBG effect_NN of_IN the_DT excreta_NN of_IN animals_NNS in_IN actual_JJ grazing_NN is_VBZ also_RB absent_JJ in_IN this_DT investigation_NN ._.
But_CC ,_, nevertheless_RB ,_, this_DT investigation_NN will_MD be_VB of_IN interest_NN and_CC practical_JJ value_NN in_IN that_DT it_PRP will_MD give_VB us_PRP the_DT nature_NN of_IN variation_NN of_IN chemical_JJ composition_NN with_IN season_NN under_IN grazing_VBG condition_NN ._.
A_DT monthly_JJ system_NN of_IN cutting_VBG has_VBZ been_VBN chosen_VBN keeping_VBG in_IN view_NN the_DT findings_NNS of_IN some_DT earlier_JJR workers_NNS who_WP showed_VBD that_IN longer_JJR intervals_NNS between_IN two_CD cuttings_NNS increase_VBP the_DT yield_NN of_IN dry_JJ matter_NN and_CC green_JJ herbage_NN but_CC decrease_VBZ the_DT contents_NNS of_IN P2O5_NNP ,_, K2O_NNP ,_, protein_NN ,_, etc_FW ._.
[_JJ Lander_NNP ,_, 1942_CD ;_: Dharmani_NNP and_CC Singh_NNP ,_, 1946_CD ;_: Woodman_NNP ,_, et_FW al._NN ,_, 1930_CD ._. ]_VB
Of_IN course_NN ,_, it_PRP will_MD also_RB be_VB interesting_JJ and_CC helpful_JJ to_TO investigate_VB the_DT effect_NN of_IN more_JJR severe_JJ and_CC more_RBR lenient_JJ system_NN of_IN cutting_VBG on_IN the_DT chemical_JJ composition_NN of_IN these_DT grasses_NNS which_WDT will_MD form_VB the_DT basis_NN of_IN another_DT investigation_NN ._.
EXPERIMENTAL_NNP Material_NNP Ten_NNP species_NNS of_IN indigenous_JJ grasses_NNS ,_, viz_NN ._.
Dichanthium_NNP annulatum_NN ,_, Amphilo-_NNP phis_NN odorata_NN ,_, Iseilema_NNP laxum_NN ,_, Themeda_NNP trimula_NN ,_, Amphilophis_NNP glabra_NN ,_, Pennisetum_NNP orientale_NN ,_, Panicum_NNP repens_VBZ ,_, Chrysopogon_NNP montanus_NN ,_, Sehima_NNP nervosum_NN and_CC Heteropogon_NNP contortus_NN were_VBD selected_VBN for_IN this_DT study_NN ._.
These_DT grasses_NNS were_VBD brought_VBN from_IN different_JJ parts_NNS of_IN the_DT country_NN and_CC established_VBN in_IN the_DT nursery_NN of_IN Agronomy_NNP Division_NNP ,_, I.A.R.I._NNP ,_, New_NNP Delhi_NNP ._.
A_DT brief_JJ description_NN of_IN three_CD of_IN these_DT grasses_NNS was_VBD given_VBN earlier_RBR [_JJ Narindar_NNP Nath_NNP and_CC Das_NNP ,_, 1952_CD ]_NN ,_, that_IN of_IN the_DT other_JJ seven_CD grasses_NNS is_VBZ given_VBN below_IN :_: 185_CD 5_CD AR/53_NNP 186_CD EFFECT_NNP OF_NNP MONTHLY_NNP CUTS_NNP ON_NNP CHEMICAL_NNP COMPOSITION_NNP [_NNP Vol_NNP ._.
XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, Dichanthium_NNP annulalum_NN (_( Stapf_NNP )_) ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ one_CD of_IN the_DT most_RBS recognised_JJ fodder_NN grasses_NNS and_CC is_VBZ known_VBN as_IN zingoo_NN ,_, kail_NN ,_, apang_NN ,_, palwan_NN and_CC gergha_NN in_IN different_JJ parts_NNS of_IN the_DT country_NN ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ a_DT perennial_JJ densely_RB tufted_JJ grass_NN occurring_VBG on_IN a_DT variety_NN of_IN soils_NNS and_CC favours_NNS medium_VBP to_TO low_VB rainfall_NN regions_NNS [_VBP Bor_NNP ,_, 1940_CD ;_: Burns_NNP ,_, 1916_CD ]_NN ._.
Duthie_NNP [_NN 1888_CD ]_NN puts_VBZ it_PRP as_IN a_DT first_JJ class_NN fodder_NN grass_NN ._.
It_PRP flowers_VBZ all_PDT the_DT cold_JJ weather_NN ._.
The_DT present_JJ data_NNS refer_NN to_TO a_DT selected_VBN strain_NN from_IN Karnal_NNP ._.
Themeda_NNP trimula_NN (_( Hack_NNP )_) ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ a_DT perennial_JJ grass_NN known_VBN as_IN barki_NN ,_, bungrat_NN ,_, gundi_NN and_CC gangdad_NN ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ considered_VBN to_TO be_VB a_DT good_JJ fodder_NN grass_NN [_NNP Blatter_NNP and_CC McCann_NNP ,_, 1935_CD ;_: Jacob_NNP ,_, 1945_CD ]_NN ._.
The_DT sample_NN of_IN the_DT grass_NN was_VBD collected_VBN from_IN Bijapur_NNP (_( Deccan_NNP )_) and_CC it_PRP flowers_VBZ very_RB late_JJ ._.
Pennisetum_NNP orientale_NN (_( Rich_NNP )_) ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ a_DT perennial_JJ grass_NN and_CC is_VBZ very_RB leafy_JJ [_NNP Bor_NNP ,_, 1940_CD ]_NN ._.
It_PRP flowers_VBZ in_IN the_DT rains_NNS and_CC early_JJ cold_NN weather_NN ._.
It_PRP shows_VBZ a_DT very_RB early_JJ spring_NN growth_NN and_CC stands_VBZ cutting_VBG well_RB ._.
This_DT collection_NN is_VBZ from_IN Simla_NNP and_CC is_VBZ locally_RB known_VBN as_IN bimalsia_NN ._.
Panicum_NN repens_NNS (_( L_NNP )_) ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ a_DT perennial_JJ glaucus_NN grass_NN ._.
It_PRP flourishes_VBZ in_IN moist_NN situations_NNS and_CC is_VBZ an_DT excellent_JJ binder_NN of_IN the_DT soil_NN ._.
When_WRB once_RB established_VBN ,_, it_PRP is_VBZ very_RB difficult_JJ to_TO get_VB rid_JJ of_IN it_PRP on_IN account_NN of_IN its_PRP$ rhizomes_NNS ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ considered_VBN to_TO be_VB one_CD of_IN the_DT most_RBS nutritious_JJ fodder_NN grasses_NNS ._.
It_PRP yields_VBZ a_DT considerable_JJ quantity_NN of_IN grain_NN also_RB ._.
The_DT sample_NN was_VBD collected_VBN from_IN Conoor_NNP and_CC is_VBZ locally_RB known_VBN as_IN silkhoo_NN ._.
Chrysopogon_NNP montanus_NN (_( Trin_NNP )_) ._.
This_DT is_VBZ an_DT extremely_RB variable_JJ perennial_JJ grass_NN growing_VBG in_IN tufts_NNS of_IN many_JJ culms_NNS and_CC leafy_NN at_IN the_DT base_NN ._.
Burns_NNS [_JJ 1916_CD ]_NN considers_NNS this_DT grass_NN as_IN an_DT excellent_JJ fodder_NN before_IN flowering_VBG though_IN the_DT leaf_NN appears_VBZ somewhat_RB coarse_JJ ._.
Bor_NNP [_NNP 1940_CD ]_NNP says_VBZ that_IN this_DT grass_NN is_VBZ not_RB suitable_JJ for_IN silage_NN ,_, as_IN it_PRP contains_VBZ too_RB much_JJ water_NN ._.
According_VBG to_TO Lisoba_NNP [_NNP 1896_CD ]_NN it_PRP is_VBZ reckoned_VBN as_IN a_DT good_JJ fodder_NN in_IN Mount_NNP Abu_NNP and_CC the_DT grain_NN is_VBZ used_VBN by_IN the_DT natives_NNS ._.
The_DT present_JJ data_NNS are_VBP collected_VBN on_IN a_DT robust_JJ strain_NN of_IN the_DT grass_NN collected_VBN from_IN Nagpur_NNP ,_, locally_RB known_VBN as_IN dhawlu_NN ._.

Sehima_NNP nervosum_NN (_( Stapf_NNP )_) ._.
A_DT perennial_JJ grass_NN growing_VBG in_IN compact_JJ tufts_NNS ._.
It_PRP tolerates_VBZ a_DT wide_JJ variety_NN of_IN soils_NNS but_CC avoids_NNS those_DT very_RB wet_JJ and_CC heavy_JJ ._.
Usually_RB found_VBN in_IN the_DT open_JJ ,_, but_CC can_MD stand_VB moderate_JJ shade_NN ._.
This_DT grass_NN can_MD stand_VB drought_RB well_RB and_CC flowers_NNS at_IN the_DT beginning_NN of_IN cold_JJ weather_NN [_NNP Bor_NNP ,_, 1940_CD ]_NN ._.
This_DT is_VBZ one_CD of_IN the_DT good_JJ fodder_NN grasses_NNS and_CC is_VBZ much_RB liked_VBN by_IN cattle_NNS ._.
According_VBG to_TO Jacob_NNP [_NNP 1945_CD ]_NNP ,_, Swhima_NNP nervosum_FW thrives_NNS under_IN partial_JJ shade_NN and_CC is_VBZ considered_VBN the_DT best_JJS forest_NN fodder_NN grass_NN and_CC is_VBZ the_DT main-stay_NN of_IN the_DT Amritmahal_NNP breed_NN of_IN cattle_NNS of_IN Mysore_NNP ._.

Heteropogon_NNP contortus_NN (_( Roem_NNP et_RB schult_NN )_) ._.
This_DT is_VBZ the_DT wellknown_JJ 'spear-grass_NN '_'' also_RB known_VBN as_IN sukla_NN and_CC kusal_NN ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ densely_RB tufted_JJ perennial_JJ grass_NN found_VBD chiefly_NN in_IN dry_JJ areas_NNS ._.
The_DT grass_NN forms_VBZ an_DT excellent_JJ hay_NN and_CC is_VBZ eaten_VBN by_IN cattle_NNS before_IN the_DT inflorescence_NN forms_NNS ._.
When_WRB the_DT fruit_NN is_VBZ mature_PDT the_DT cattle_NNS avoid_VBP it_PRP ,_, the_DT awned_JJ fruit_NN cause_NN severe_JJ sores_NNS in_IN the_DT gums_NNS and_CC mouths_NNS of_IN cattle._NN ``_``

In_IN other_JJ districts_NNS it_PRP is_VBZ said_VBD to_TO be_VB eaten_VBN only_RB by_IN buffaloes_NNS when_WRB they_PRP are_VBP hungry_JJ and_CC can_MD not_RB get_VB other_JJ kinds_NNS of_IN grasses_NNS ``_`` September_NNP ,_, 1953_CD ]_NN N._NNP NATH_NNP AND_NNP N._NNP B._NNP DAS_NNP 187_CD Sampling_NNP of_IN grasses_NNS The_DT samples_NNS of_IN different_JJ species_NNS of_IN grasses_NNS were_VBD collected_VBN by_IN hand_NN cutting_VBG nearly_RB all_PDT the_DT surface_NN growth_NN of_IN the_DT plants_NNS ,_, leaving_VBG only_RB about_IN one_CD inch_NN of_IN the_DT herbage_NN ._.
All_PDT these_DT grasses_NNS have_VBP been_VBN grown_VBN in_IN sub-plots_JJ each_DT comprising_VBG an_DT area_NN of_IN 1/300_CD of_IN an_DT acre_NN ._.
A_DT fixed_JJ number_NN of_IN plants_NNS of_IN each_DT grass_NN were_VBD cut_VBN repeatedly_RB after_IN every_DT 30_CD days_NNS beginning_VBG from_IN May_NNP 2_CD ,_, 1949_CD ._.
The_DT rest_NN of_IN the_DT plants_NNS were_VBD left_VBN undisturbed_JJ throughout_IN the_DT period_NN of_IN investigation_NN ._.
The_DT weights_NNS of_IN green_JJ material_NN obtained_VBN for_IN each_DT cutting_VBG for_IN each_DT grass_NN were_VBD recorded_VBN in_IN the_DT field_NN ._.
The_DT samples_NNS were_VBD immediately_RB taken_VBN to_TO the_DT laboratory_NN ,_, chopped_VBD to_TO small_JJ pieces_NNS and_CC a_DT representative_JJ part_NN of_IN each_DT sample_NN was_VBD dried_VBN in_IN oven_NN for_IN moisture_NN content_NN ._.
The_DT dried_JJ material_NN was_VBD ground_NN and_CC kept_NN in_IN stoppered_JJ bottles_NNS for_IN further_JJ analysis_NN ._.

I_PRP ._.
Out_IN of_IN all_PDT these_DT grasses_NNS Themeda_NNP trimula_NN gives_VBZ the_DT highest_JJS average_JJ crude_NN protein_NN content_NN ._.
Seasonal_JJ variation_NN of_IN chemical_NN composition_NN The_DT general_JJ trend_NN of_IN variations_NNS in_IN ._.
various_JJ chemical_NN constituents_NNS is_VBZ shown_VBN by_IN the_DT monthly_JJ averages_NNS of_IN different_JJ constituents_NNS of_IN all_PDT the_DT grasses_NNS ._.
The_DT variations_NNS in_IN the_DT more_RBR important_JJ constituents_NNS namely_RB ,_, phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ,_, lime_NN ,_, crude_NN protein_NN ,_, crude_VBP fibre_JJ and_CC original_JJ moisture_NN as_IN also_RB in_IN lime/phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ratio_NN and_CC yield_NN of_IN green_JJ matter_NN for_IN each_DT cutting_NN are_VBP indicated_VBN in_IN Fig_NNP ._.
II_NNP ._.
It_PRP shows_VBZ that_IN the_DT variations_NNS in_IN moisture_NN ,_, crude_NN protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN were_VBD similar_JJ ,_, while_IN lime_NN ,_, crude_VBP fibre_JJ varied_VBD inversely_RB with_IN each_DT of_IN the_DT above_NN mentioned_VBD constituents_NNS ._.
The_DT data_NN further_RBR show_NN that_IN crude_NN ash_NN ,_, ether_CC extract_NN also_RB tended_VBD to_TO follow_VB crude_NN protein_IN quite_RB consis-_JJ tantly_RB ,_, while_IN nitrogen-free-extract_JJ was_VBD correlated_VBN with_IN crude_NN fibre_NN ._.
A_DT further_JJ comparison_NN of_IN the_DT average_JJ data_NNS with_IN those_DT for_IN individual_JJ species_NNS shows_VBZ that_IN there_EX was_VBD a_DT good_JJ deal_NN of_IN similarity_NN in_IN the_DT changes_NNS occurring_VBG in_IN the_DT chemical_NN composition_NN of_IN each_DT of_IN the_DT ten_JJ species_NNS during_IN the_DT whole_NN of_IN the_DT investigation_NN ._.

Yield_NN of_IN green_JJ matter_NN Table_NNP II_NNP shows_VBZ the_DT yield_NN of_IN green_JJ matter_NN obtained_VBN for_IN each_DT cutting_VBG for_IN different_JJ species_NNS of_IN grasses_NNS ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ seen_VBN that_IN the_DT maximum_JJ yield_NN in_IN most_JJS of_IN the_DT grasses_NNS was_VBD obtained_VBN in_IN the_DT first_JJ cutting_NN ,_, which_WDT represented_VBD accumulated_VBD spring_NN growth_NN ._.
After_IN this_DT the_DT yield_NN continuously_RB decreased_VBD wth_NN each_DT successive_JJ cut_NN upto_VBD the_DT beginning_NN of_IN July_NNP ,_, i.e._NN ,_, the_DT third_JJ cut_NN ._.
With_IN the_DT incidence_NN of_IN heavy_JJ rainfall_NN during_IN July_NNP which_WDT resulted_VBD in_IN favourable_JJ soil_NN humidity_NN and_CC favourable_JJ temperature_NN condition_NN ,_, the_DT plants_NNS showed_VBD vigorous_JJ growth_NN ._.
The_DT result_NN was_VBD that_IN the_DT yield_NN of_IN green_JJ matter_NN of_IN samples_NNS increased_VBN considerably_RB and_CC in_IN some_DT cases_NNS was_VBD even_RB higher_JJR than_IN that_DT in_IN first_JJ cutting_NN ._.
Thus_RB in_IN case_NN of_IN Themeda_NNP trimula_NN ,_, samples_NNS collected_VBD during_IN this_DT period_NN on_IN 31_CD July_NNP recorded_VBD 14.5_CD lb_NN ._.
of_IN green_JJ matter_NN against_IN 10_CD lb_NN ._.
in_IN the_DT first_JJ cutting_NN ._.

It_PRP is_VBZ seen_VBN that_IN the_DT changes_NNS are_VBP closely_RB corre-_JJ lated_VBN to_TO each_DT other_JJ ._.
The_DT difference_NN between_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC true_JJ protein_NN in_IN continuously_RB cut_VBN grasses_NNS averages_NNS about_IN 10_CD per_IN cent_NN of_IN the_DT crude_NN protein_NN ._.

It_PRP is_VBZ seen_VBN that_IN the_DT two_CD constituents_NNS displayed_VBD variations_NNS opposite_RB to_TO each_DT other_JJ throughout_IN the_DT investigation_NN ._.
Phosphoric_NNP acid_NN contents_NNS of_IN the_DT grasses_NNS increased_VBD after_IN the_DT first_JJ cutting_VBG while_IN lime_JJ content_NN slightly_RB decreased_VBN ._.
The_DT opposite_JJ variations_NNS in_IN the_DT two_CD constituents_NNS became_VBD marked_VBN in_IN the_DT most_RBS humid_JJ part_NN of_IN the_DT season_NN ._.
The_DT samples_NNS collected_VBN on_IN 31_CD July_NNP after_IN the_DT heaviest_JJS monthly_JJ rainfall_NN recorded_VBD maximum_JJ phosphoric_JJ acid_NN content_NN and_CC minimum_JJ lime_NN content_NN ._.

It_PRP is_VBZ noteworthy_JJ that_IN though_IN the_DT percentage_NN of_IN phosphoric_JJ acid_NN decreased_VBN at_IN the_DT end_NN of_IN the_DT investigation_NN the_DT value_NN was_VBD still_RB higher_JJR than_IN that_DT in_IN the_DT first_JJ cutting_NN ._.
This_DT maintenance_NN of_IN high_JJ percentage_NN of_IN phosphoric_JJ acid_NN is_VBZ the_DT result_NN of_IN systematic_JJ continuous_JJ cutting_VBG on_IN the_DT grasses_NNS and_CC is_VBZ thus_RB of_IN practical_JJ significance_NN ._.
It_PRP has_VBZ been_VBN reported_VBN that_IN phosphoric_JJ acid_NN content_NN of_IN Indian_JJ grasses_NNS is_VBZ low_JJ ,_, but_CC in_IN this_DT investigation_NN it_PRP has_VBZ been_VBN found_VBN that_IN phosphoric_JJ acid_NN remained_VBD fairly_RB high_JJ throughout_IN and_CC even_RB in_IN certain_JJ cases_NNS exceeded_VBD the_DT lime_NN content_NN ._.

XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, Lime/Phosphoric_NNP acid_VBZ ratio_VB Another_DT factor_NN responsible_JJ for_IN the_DT proper_JJ assimilation_NN of_IN the_DT two_CD constituents_NNS is_VBZ the_DT ratio_NN in_IN which_WDT these_DT minerals_NNS occur_VBP in_IN the_DT rations_NNS of_IN animals_NNS ._.
As_IN stated_VBN before_IN these_DT constituents_NNS in_IN a_DT well-balanced_JJ ration_NN should_MD be_VB present_JJ in_IN an_DT approximate_JJ ratio_NN of_IN 1_CD to_TO 1.5_CD parts_NNS of_IN lime_NN for_IN each_DT part_NN of_IN phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ seen_VBN that_IN monthly_JJ cutting_VBG keeps_VBZ the_DT lime/phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ratio_NN (_( Table_NNP XIII_NNP )_) quite_RB near_IN to_TO the_DT standard_NN ;_: but_CC in_IN certain_JJ cases_NNS wider_VBP or_CC narrower_JJR ratio_NN was_VBD also_RB obtained_VBN ._.
The_DT wider_NN ratio_NN (_( excess_NN of_IN CaO_NNP over_IN P2O5_NNP )_) was_VBD obtained_VBN in_IN some_DT samples_NNS collected_VBN during_IN dry_JJ months_NNS ,_, i.e_NN ._.
in_IN the_DT beginning_NN of_IN May_NNP and_CC end_NN of_IN October_NNP ;_: while_IN narrower_JJR values_NNS (_( excess_NN of_IN P2O5_NNP over_IN CaO_NNP )_) was_VBD obtained_VBN in_IN some_DT samples_NNS collected_VBN at_IN the_DT end_NN of_IN July_NNP ,_, which_WDT month_NN also_RB had_VBD the_DT heaviest_JJS rainfall_NN ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ ,_, therefore_RB ,_, recommended_VBD that_IN rations_NNS composed_VBD solely_RB of_IN these_DT grasses_NNS individually_RB may_MD with_IN advantage_NN be_VB supplemented_VBN with_IN phosphoric_JJ acid_NN concentrates_NNS during_IN very_RB dry_JJ periods_NNS ._.
While_IN lime_JJ concentrates_NNS may_MD be_VB added_VBN during_IN very_RB humid_JJ period_NN to_TO get_VB a_DT balanced_JJ ration_NN as_IN regards_NNS these_DT minerals_NNS ._.
But_CC it_PRP will_MD not_RB be_VB advisable_JJ to_TO add_VB P205_NNP concentrates_NNS to_TO rations_NNS composed_VBN of_IN Pennisetum_NNP orientale_NN and_CC Panicum_NNP repens_NNS at_IN any_DT part_NN of_IN the_DT seasons_NNS ._.

The_DT CaO/P2O5_NNP ratio_NN tended_VBD to_TO deviate_VB less_RBR from_IN the_DT standard_NN in_IN case_NN of_IN Dichan_NNP thium_NN annulatum_NN ,_, Heteropogon_NNP contortus_NN ,_, Amphilophis_NNP glabra_NN and_CC Themeda_NNP trimula_NN and_CC therefore_IN these_DT grasses_NNS may_MD be_VB taken_VBN best_RB as_IN regards_NNS mineral_JJ nutrition_NN under_IN monthly_JJ system_NN of_IN cutting_VBG ._.

r.*_NN Significance_NNP Corr_NNP ._.

r._NN Significance_NNP Dichanthium_NNP annulatum_VBZ +0.9160_NNP Highly_NNP significant_JJ September_NNP ,_, 1953_CD ]_NN N._NNP NATH_NNP AND_NNP N._NNP B._NNP DAS_NNP 203_CD correlation_NN co-efficients_NNS in_IN case_NN of_IN Iseilema_NNP laxum_NN to_TO positive_JJ ones_NNS in_IN case_NN of_IN Amphi-_NNP lophis_NN odorata_NN and_CC Amphilophis_NNP glabra_NN ._.
Most_JJS of_IN the_DT grasses_NNS have_VBP negative_JJ though_IN ._.
not_RB significant_JJ correlation_NN co-efficients_NNS between_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC lime_NN ._.
This_DT leads_VBZ to_TO the_DT conclusion_NN that_IN the_DT positive_JJ correlation_NN co-efficients_NNS between_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN indicate_VBP some_DT sort_NN of_IN association_NN between_IN the_DT two_CD constituents_NNS in_IN continuously_RB cut_VBN grasses_NNS ._.
SUMMARY_JJ Investigations_NNS were_VBD undertaken_VBN to_TO study_VB the_DT effect_NN of_IN monthly_JJ cuts_NNS on_IN the_DT chemical_JJ composition_NN of_IN ten_JJ Indian_JJ grasses_NNS ._.
(_( 1_CD )_) Monthly_NNP cuts_NNS were_VBD found_VBN to_TO maintain_VB the_DT protein_NN ,_, phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ,_, lime_NN and_CC ether_NN extract_JJ contents_NNS of_IN different_JJ grasses_NNS fairly_RB high_JJ during_IN the_DT period_NN of_IN investiga-_JJ tion_NN ._.
The_DT percentage_NN of_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN seldom_NN fell_VBD below_IN that_DT recorded_VBD for_IN the_DT first_JJ cutting_NN ._.
While_IN considerably_RB higher_JJR values_NNS were_VBD obtained_VBN in_IN the_DT samples_NNS collected_VBN after_IN the_DT onset_NN of_IN rains_NNS ._.
Lime_NNP phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ratio_NN deviated_VBD less_RBR from_IN the_DT standard_NN in_IN most_JJS of_IN the_DT cases_NNS under_IN monthly_JJ system_NN of_IN cutting_VBG ._.
(_( 2_CD )_) There_EX was_VBD a_DT close_JJ parallelism_NN between_IN the_DT variations_NNS in_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN throughout_IN the_DT investigation_NN ,_, while_IN lime_JJ generally_RB varied_VBN inversely_RB to_TO both_DT of_IN them_PRP ._.
(_( 3_CD )_) Ether_NNP extract_NN increased_VBD with_IN crude_NN protein_NN after_IN first_JJ cutting_VBG but_CC afterwards_NNS was_VBD subjected_VBN to_TO less_JJR variations_NNS which_WDT were_VBD not_RB regular_JJ in_IN all_PDT the_DT species_NNS ._.
There_EX was_VBD sharp_JJ decline_NN in_IN ether_CC extract_JJ content_NN of_IN all_DT grasses_NNS at_IN the_DT end_NN of_IN the_DT investigation_NN ._.
(_( 4_CD )_) Crude_NNP fibre_NN and_CC nitrogen-free-extract_JJ tended_VBD to_TO display_VB variations_NNS opposite_JJ to_TO crude_VB protein_NN ,_, but_CC crude_VBP fibre_NN was_VBD somewhat_RB variant_JJ throughout_IN ._.
(_( 5_CD )_) Crude_NNP ash_NN ,_, silica_NN and_CC insoluble_JJ residue_NN ,_, and_CC silica-free-ash_JJ varied_VBN in_IN a_DT way_NN similar_JJ to_TO crude_VB protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN but_CC variations_NNS in_IN silica-free-ash_NN were_VBD not_RB so_RB regular_JJ ._.
(_( 6_CD )_) Changes_NNS in_IN original_JJ moisture_NN were_VBD related_VBN to_TO crude_VB protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN ._.
(_( 7_CD )_) Yields_NNS of_IN green_JJ matter_NN ,_, dry_JJ matter_NN ,_, crude_NN protein_NN ,_, lime_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN per_IN acre_NN for_IN different_JJ grasses_NNS have_VBP been_VBN calculated_VBN ._.
Maximum_NNP output_NN of_IN different_JJ constituents_NNS was_VBD obtained_VBN in_IN case_NN of_IN Themeda_NNP trimula_NN ,_, while_IN it_PRP was_VBD least_VBN in_IN Iseilema_NNP laxum_NN ._.
(_( 8_CD )_) Statistical_NNP examination_NN of_IN the_DT results_NNS gave_VBD positive_JJ and_CC in_IN most_JJS cases_NNS signi-_JJ ficant_JJ correlation_NN co-efficients_NNS between_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC phosphoric_JJ acid_NN contents_NNS of_IN different_JJ grasses_NNS indicating_VBG some_DT sort_NN of_IN association_NN between_IN the_DT two_CD ._.
Correla-_JJ tion_NN co-efficients_NNS in_IN case_NN of_IN crude_NN protein_NN and_CC lime_JJ varied_VBN from_IN highly_RB significant_JJ negative_JJ correlation_NN co-efficients_NNS to_TO positive_JJ ones_NNS ,_, but_CC in_IN most_JJS of_IN the_DT grasses_NNS ,_, the_DT correlation_NN co-efficients_NNS were_VBD negative_JJ though_IN not_RB significant_JJ ._.

20_CD ,_, 53_CD EFFECT_NNP OF_NNP SHADING_NNP AND_NNP SPRINKLING_NNP ON_NNP CATTLE_NNP AND_NNP BUFFALOES_NNP IN_NNP EGYPT_NNP By_IN M._NNP T._NNP RAGAB_NNP ,_, M._NNP A._NNP GHANY_NNP ,_, and_CC A_NNP ._.
A._NN ASKER_NNP ,_, Animal_NNP Breeding_NNP Department_NNP ,_, Faculty_NNP of_IN Agriculture_NNP ,_, Fouad_NNP I_PRP University_NNP ,_, Cairo_NNP ,_, Egypt_NNP (_( Received_VBN for_IN publication_NN on_IN 13_CD February_NNP ,_, 1952_CD )_) THE_DT summer_NN season_NN in_IN Egypt_NNP was_VBD found_VBN to_TO be_VB the_DT most_RBS critical_JJ season_NN of_IN the_DT ,_, year_NN as_RB far_RB as_IN the_DT comfort_NN of_IN cattle_NNS and_CC buffaloes_NNS is_VBZ concerned_VBN [_JJ Badreldin_NNP ,_, et_RB al_NN ._.
1951_CD ]_NN ._.
When_WRB animals_NNS were_VBD exposed_VBN to_TO sun_VB during_IN summer_NN ,_, the_DT buffaloes_NNS showed_VBD more_RBR discomfort_NN than_IN cattle_NNS [_JJ Asker_NNP ,_, et_FW al._NN ,_, 1952_CD ]_NN ._.
In_IN many_JJ other_JJ countries_NNS ,_, cooling_VBG treatments_NNS have_VBP been_VBN tried_VBN to_TO keep_VB the_DT animals_NNS in_IN comfort_NN during_IN the_DT hot_JJ season_NN of_IN the_DT year_NN with_IN more_RBR or_CC less_JJR success_NN ._.
Minett_NNP [_NN 1947_CD ]_NN ,_, Sinha_NNP and_CC Minett_NNP [_NNP 1947_CD ]_NNP ,_, showed_VBD that_IN ,_, hosing_VBG ,_, sprinkling_VBG or_CC wallowing_VBG in_IN water_NN ,_, caused_VBD an_DT appreciable_JJ reduction_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN of_IN both_DT cattle_NNS and_CC buffaloes_NNS ._.
Seath_NNP and_CC Miller_NNP [_NNP 1947-1948_JJ ]_NN found_VBD that_IN either_DT shade_NN alone_RB ,_, or_CC water_NN sprinkling_NN followed_VBN by_IN shade_NN reduced_VBD the_DT body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN of_IN dairy_NN cattle_NNS ._.
They_PRP also_RB observed_VBD that_IN combining_VBG the_DT two_CD procedures_NNS was_VBD more_RBR effective_JJ in_IN bringing_VBG the_DT animals_NNS back_RB to_TO their_PRP$ normal_JJ conditions_NNS ._.
In_IN this_DT study_NN ,_, it_PRP was_VBD interesting_VBG to_TO investigate_VB the_DT effect_NN of_IN shading_NN and_CC sprinkling_VBG on_IN body_NN temperature_NN ,_, respiration_NN and_CC pulse_JJ rates_NNS during_IN the_DT hot_JJ days_NNS of_IN the_DT summer_NN season_NN ._.
The_DT experiment_NN was_VBD carried_VBN out_RP on_IN buffaloes_NNS ,_, Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS ,_, pure_NN Jerseys_NNP ,_, pure_NN and_CC graded_VBD Shorthorn_NNP cows_NNS ._.
MATERIAL_NNP AND_NNP EXPERIMENTAL_NNP PROCEDURE_NNP Five_NNP groups_NNS of_IN mature_NN females_NNS were_VBD used_VBN in_IN this_DT study_NN ._.
The_DT first_JJ group_NN was_VBD composed_VBN of_IN eight_CD buffaloes_NNS ,_, the_DT second_NN of_IN nine_CD Egyptian_JJ cows_NNS ,_, the_DT third_JJ of_IN two_CD pure_NN Jerseys_NNP ,_, the_DT fourth_JJ of_IN three_CD pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP ,_, and_CC the_DT fifth_NN of_IN eight_CD graded_VBN Shorthorns_NNP ._.
Animals_NNS after_IN being_VBG exposed_VBN to_TO sun_VB for_IN two_CD hours_NNS ,_, between_IN 10-12_JJ A.M._NNP ,_, for_IN six_CD hot_JJ days_NNS [_MD Asker_NNP ,_, et_FW al._NN ,_, 1952_CD ]_NN ,_, were_VBD subjected_VBN to_TO different_JJ cooling_NN treatments_NNS ._.
They_PRP were_VBD either_RB put_VBN dry_JJ under_IN shade_NN ,_, indoor_NN or_CC outdoor_NN ,_, or_CC were_VBD sprinkled_VBN before_IN shading_NN ._.
The_DT shading_NN indoor_NN took_VBD place_NN by_IN installing_VBG the_DT animals_NNS in_IN a_DT covered_JJ milking_NN stable_JJ ,_, while_IN shading_VBG outdoor_JJ took_VBD place_NN under_IN big_JJ shady_NN trees_NNS ._.
Sprinkling_VBG was_VBD made_VBN by_IN a_DT specially_RB constructed_VBN shower_NN which_WDT enabled_VBD the_DT water_NN to_TO cover_VB the_DT animals_NNS from_IN all_DT possible_JJ sides_NNS ._.
Body_NN temperature_NN ,_, respiration_NN rate_NN and_CC pulse_JJ rate_NN were_VBD hourly_RB measured_VBN ,_, in_IN the_DT usual_JJ ways_NNS ,_, during_IN the_DT time_NN of_IN exposure_NN and_CC cooling_NN ._.
Also_RB the_DT average_JJ air_NN temperature_NN and_CC relative_JJ humidity_NN were_VBD recorded_VBN during_IN the_DT period_NN of_IN study_NN (_( Table_NNP I_PRP )_) ._.

RESULTS_RB 1_CD ._.
Shading_VBG outdoor_NN In_IN this_DT treatment_NN ,_, buffaloes_NNS ,_, Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS and_CC pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP were_VBD only_RB used_VBN ._.
After_IN one_CD hour_NN of_IN shading_NN ,_, body_NN temperature_NN ,_, respiration_NN and_CC pulse_JJ rates_NNS decreased_VBN in_IN variable_JJ rates_NNS and_CC differently_RB ,_, according_VBG to_TO the_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS used_VBN ._.
Body_NN temperature_NN decreased_VBD more_JJR remarkably_RB in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN buffaloes_NNS and_CC Shorthorns_NNP than_IN Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
The_DT rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN was_VBD 1.3_CD per_IN cent_NN and_CC 0.26_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN the_DT two_CD former_JJ groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS and_CC the_DT latter_JJ one_CD respectively_RB ._.
As_RB far_RB as_IN respiration_NN rate_NN was_VBD concerned_VBN ,_, the_DT percentage_NN of_IN decrease_NN was_VBD far_RB much_RB greater_JJR than_IN in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN body_NN temperature_NN ._.
The_DT decrease_NN was_VBD 52.3_CD per_IN cent_NN ,_, 47.8_CD per_IN cent_NN and_CC 24.5_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN buffaloes_NNS ,_, pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP and_CC Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS respectively_RB ._.
The_DT decrease_NN in_IN pulse_JJ rate_NN was_VBD different_JJ in_IN its_PRP$ magnitude_NN than_IN either_DT body_NN temperature_NN or_CC respiration_NN rate_NN ;_: it_PRP was_VBD greater_JJR in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP being_VBG 8.2_CD per_IN cent_NN compared_VBN to_TO 3.7_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN buffaloes_NNS and_CC 4.5_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
At_IN the_DT end_NN of_IN the_DT second_JJ hour_NN in_IN shade_NN ,_, body_NN temperature_NN decreased_VBN in_IN both_DT buffaloes_NNS and_CC native_JJ cattle_NNS ,_, while_IN practically_RB no_DT further_JJ decrease_NN was_VBD noticed_VBN in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN Shorthorns_NNP ._.
The_DT decrease_NN was_VBD 1.8_CD per_IN cent_NN and_CC 0.52_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN buffaloes_NNS and_CC Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS from_IN the_DT initial_JJ body_NN temperature_NN after_IN exposure_NN to_TO sun_VB ._.
The_DT respiration_NN rate_NN after_IN two_CD hours_NNS of_IN shading_VBG continued_VBN to_TO decrease_VB in_IN all_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS The_DT decrease_NN was_VBD more_RBR noticeable_JJ in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN buffaloes_NNS and_CC pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP ._.
The_DT pulse_NN rate_NN also_RB continued_VBD to_TO decrease_VB after_IN shading_VBG for_IN two_CD hours_NNS in_IN all_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS ._.
The_DT Egyptian_JJ cattle_NN was_VBD noticed_VBN to_TO show_VB the_DT less_JJR rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN either_CC after_IN one_CD or_CC two_CD hours_NNS of_IN shading_VBG ._.

A._NN ASKER_NNP 209_CD 2_CD ._.
Shading_VBG indoors_NNS There_EX was_VBD a_DT decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN of_IN the_DT animals_NNS after_IN staying_VBG in_IN the_DT shade_NN for_IN one_CD hour_NN (_( Table_NNP III_NNP )_) ._.
The_DT rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN was_VBD in_IN the_DT following_JJ order_NN :_: First_RB ,_, the_DT pure_NN Shorthorn_NNP ,_, then_RB buffaloes_VBZ ,_, pure_JJ Jerseys_NNP ,_, Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS ,_, followed_VBD lastly_RB by_IN native_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
The_DT decrease_NN in_IN respiration_NN rate_NN was_VBD highest_JJS in_IN buffaloes_NNS being_VBG 50.8_CD per_IN cent_NN followed_VBN by_IN pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP ,_, Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS (_( both_DT 38.3_CD per_IN cent_NN )_) ,_, then_RB the_DT pure_NN Jerseys_NNP (_( 33.8_CD per_IN cent_NN )_) and_CC then_RB the_DT native_JJ cattle_NNS (_( 31.6_CD per_IN cent_NN )_) ._.
The_DT change_NN in_IN pulse_JJ rate_NN did_VBD not_RB follow_VB the_DT same_JJ trend_NN previously_RB noticed_VBN for_IN body_NN temperature_NN or_CC respiration_NN rate_NN ._.
After_IN two_CD hours_NNS of_IN shading_VBG the_DT animals_NNS ,_, body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN continued_VBD to_TO decrease_VB in_IN all_DT groups_NNS except_IN the_DT native_JJ cattle_NNS ,_, which_WDT did_VBD not_RB show_VB any_DT change_NN ,_, while_IN the_DT pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP were_VBD slightly_RB affected_VBN ._.
The_DT pulse_NN rate_NN ,_, decreased_VBN in_IN all_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS except_IN the_DT pure_NN Jerseys_NNP and_CC Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS ._.
The_DT rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN after_IN one_CD hour_NN of_IN shading_VBG indoor_NN was_VBD in_IN general_JJ less_JJR than_IN that_DT of_IN shading_VBG outdoor_NN ._.
This_DT may_MD be_VB due_JJ to_TO the_DT effect_NN of_IN air_NN movement_NN outdoor_NN which_WDT will_MD undoubtedly_RB have_VB a_DT decreasing_JJ effect_NN on_IN body_NN temperatue_NN ._.
3_CD ._.
Sprinkling_VBG for_IN three_CD minutes_NNS followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG indoor_NN for_IN one_CD hour_NN The_DT effect_NN of_IN this_DT treatment_NN on_IN animals_NNS was_VBD much_RB pronounced_VBN in_IN body_NN tempera-_JJ ture_NN ,_, respiration_NN rate_NN and_CC pulse_NN rate_NN than_IN shading_VBG only_RB for_IN one_CD hour_NN (_( Table_NNP IV_NNP )_) ._.
This_DT is_VBZ due_JJ to_TO the_DT combined_JJ effect_NN of_IN sprinkling_NN and_CC shading_NN ._.
The_DT effect_NN of_IN sprinkling_NN is_VBZ mainly_RB due_JJ to_TO the_DT heat_NN loss_NN which_WDT happens_VBZ as_IN a_DT result_NN to_TO the_DT vaporization_NN of_IN water_NN from_IN the_DT surface_NN of_IN the_DT animal_NN 's_POS body_NN ._.
4_CD ._.
Sprinkling_VBG for_IN three_CD minutes_NNS followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG outdoor_NN for_IN two_CD hours_NNS It_PRP is_VBZ noticed_VBN from_IN Table_NNP V_NNP that_IN this_DT treatment_NN caused_VBD a_DT decrease_NN in_IN each_DT of_IN the_DT three_CD items_NNS after_IN one_CD hour_NN and_CC two_CD hours_NNS ._.
The_DT rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN after_IN one_CD hour_NN was_VBD just_RB the_DT same_JJ as_IN that_DT of_IN the_DT previous_JJ treatment_NN (_( No_UH ._.
3_CD )_) in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS only_RB ._.
The_DT decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN of_IN buffaloes_NNS and_CC native_JJ cattle_NNS was_VBD 1.8_CD per_IN cent_NN and_CC 0.52_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN both_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS respec-_JJ tively_RB ._.
The_DT rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN pure_NN Jerseys_NNP and_CC pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP was_VBD not_RB much_JJ different_JJ than_IN what_WP was_VBD noticed_VBN for_IN other_JJ groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS ._.
After_IN two_CD hours_NNS of_IN shading_VBG indoor_NN ,_, no_RB much_JJ change_NN was_VBD noticed_VBN in_IN the_DT body_NN temperature_NN of_IN both_DT Egyptian_NNP cattle_NNS and_CC Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS ._.
In_IN all_DT other_JJ groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS body_NN temperature_NN kept_VBD on_IN decreasing_VBG with_IN the_DT buffaloes_NNS having_VBG the_DT highest_JJS rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN ._.
The_DT respiration_NN rate_NN did_VBD not_RB change_VB considerably_RB after_IN two_CD hours_NNS of_IN shading_VBG in_IN all_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS ._.
It_PRP seems_VBZ that_IN the_DT change_NN in_IN this_DT item_NN takes_VBZ place_NN after_IN putting_VBG the_DT animals_NNS in_IN the_DT shade_NN ,_, but_CC did_VBD not_RB appreciably_RB change_NN since_IN that_DT time_NN ._.
The_DT pulse_JJ rate_NN did_VBD not_RB follow_VB a_DT clear_JJ cut_NN trend_NN in_IN all_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS ._.
It_PRP is_VBZ worth_JJ noting_VBG that_IN ,_, when_WRB sprinkling_VBG was_VBD practised_VBN before_IN shading_NN ,_, pulse_NN rate_NN showed_VBD a_DT slight_JJ increase_NN in_IN some_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS ._.

A._NN ASKER_NNP 213_CD 5_CD ._.
Sprinkling_VBG for_IN five_CD minutes_NNS followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG outdoor_NN for_IN one_CD hour_NN As_IN it_PRP is_VBZ shown_VBN in_IN Table_NNP VI_NNP ,_, this_DT procedure_NN caused_VBD a_DT decline_NN in_IN both_DT body_NN tem-_JJ perature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN in_IN all_DT groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS except_IN native_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
The_DT difference_NN between_IN the_DT effect_NN of_IN this_DT treatment_NN and_CC that_IN of_IN sprinkling_VBG for_IN three_CD minutes_NNS then_RB shading_VBG outdoor_NN for_IN one_CD hour_NN was_VBD not_RB appreciable_JJ ._.
Increasing_VBG the_DT time_NN of_IN sprinkling_VBG from_IN 3_CD to_TO 5_CD minutes_NNS does_VBZ not_RB seem_VB to_TO be_VB responsible_JJ for_IN making_VBG the_DT animals_NNS feel_VBP more_RBR comfortable_JJ ._.
The_DT pulse_JJ rate_NN as_IN in_IN all_DT other_JJ treatments_NNS was_VBD not_RB consistent_JJ in_IN its_PRP$ magnitude_NN ._.
DISCUSSION_NNP AND_CC CONCLUSIONS_NNP The_DT use_NN of_IN shade_NN whether_IN outdoor_NN or_CC indoor_NN ,_, preceded_VBN by_IN a_DT sprinkling_NN ,_, was_VBD investigated_VBN as_IN a_DT means_NN of_IN combatting_VBG the_DT unfavourable_JJ effects_NNS of_IN hot_JJ atmospheric_JJ conditions_NNS on_IN buffaloes_NNS ,_, Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS ,_, pure_NN and_CC graded_VBD Shorthorns_NNP and_CC pure_JJ Jerseys_NNP ._.
The_DT idea_NN of_IN trying_VBG those_DT different_JJ procedures_NNS was_VBD to_TO know_VB the_DT best_JJS system_NN of_IN management_NN which_WDT will_MD be_VB more_RBR elaborate_JJ in_IN keeping_VBG those_DT animals_NNS comfortable_JJ under_IN Egyptian_JJ summer_NN conditions_NNS ._.
The_DT methods_NNS of_IN sprinkling_VBG adopted_VBN in_IN this_DT investigation_NN did_VBD not_RB cause_VB a_DT remarkable_JJ decline_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN ,_, respiration_NN rate_NN and_CC pulse_JJ rate_NN of_IN animals_NNS to_TO justify_VB its_PRP$ use_NN ._.
This_DT may_MD be_VB due_JJ to_TO the_DT limited_JJ air_NN movement_NN at_IN such_JJ time_NN of_IN the_DT year_NN ._.
Moreover_RB ,_, sprinkling_VBG was_VBD practised_VBN for_IN a_DT rather_RB short_JJ time_NN (_( 3_CD and_CC 5_CD minutes_NNS )_) ,_, com-_JJ pared_VBD to_TO longer_JJR periods_NNS of_IN time_NN previously_RB recorded_VBN by_IN Seath_NNP and_CC Miller_NNP [_NNP 1947_CD ,_, 1948a_CD and_CC 1948b_CD ]_NN ._.
Sprinkling_VBG ,_, hosing_VBG or_CC any_DT other_JJ water_NN wetting_VBG device_NN ,_, would_MD not_RB appreciably_RB affect_VB the_DT animals_NNS '_POS temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN unless_IN they_PRP are_VBP either_DT practised_VBN on_IN the_DT animals_NNS for_IN a_DT sufficiently_RB long_JJ time_NN or_CC followed_VBN by_IN an_DT artificial_JJ moving_VBG current_JJ of_IN air_NN ._.
Thus_RB the_DT animals_NNS could_MD keep_VB their_PRP$ normal_JJ body_NN temperature_NN through_IN the_DT dissipation_NN of_IN excess_JJ heat_NN by_IN conduction_NN and_CC vapori-_JJ zation_NN ._.
Sprinkling_VBG ,_, in_IN general_JJ ,_, is_VBZ not_RB the_DT kind_NN of_IN treatment_NN which_WDT is_VBZ advised_VBN to_TO the_DT Egyptian_JJ farmer_NN ,_, since_IN it_PRP needs_VBZ special_JJ devices_NNS not_RB available_JJ in_IN the_DT country_NN at_IN the_DT present_JJ time_NN ,_, and_CC if_IN sought_VBN ,_, they_PRP will_MD be_VB costly_JJ and_CC beyond_IN his_PRP$ means_NNS ._.
When_WRB sprinkling_NN was_VBD followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG ,_, the_DT combined_JJ effect_NN resulted_VBD in_IN bringing_VBG the_DT animals_NNS to_TO their_PRP$ normal_JJ conditions_NNS more_RBR rapidly_RB after_IN one_CD hour_NN of_IN shading_NN ._.
Shading_VBG was_VBD proved_VBN to_TO be_VB the_DT most_RBS favourable_JJ cooling_NN treatment_NN discussed_VBN in_IN this_DT study_NN ._.
When_WRB it_PRP was_VBD practised_VBN outdoor_RB ,_, its_PRP$ effect_NN was_VBD noticed_VBN quickly_RB and_CC in_IN a_DT more_RBR pronounced_JJ way_NN than_IN in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN indoors_NNS ._.
The_DT abundance_NN of_IN shade_NN outdoor_NN where_WRB there_EX are_VBP trees_NNS ,_, makes_VBZ this_DT system_NN of_IN cooling_VBG the_DT most_RBS appropriate_JJ and_CC highly_RB recommended_VBD to_TO the_DT farmer_NN in_IN this_DT country_NN ._.
At_IN any_DT rate_NN ,_, if_IN animal_JJ production_NN is_VBZ to_TO be_VB practised_VBN more_RBR intensively_RB in_IN the_DT Egyptian_JJ agriculture_NN ,_, it_PRP becomes_VBZ necessary_JJ to_TO think_VB of_IN building_NN airy_NN and_CC shady_JJ types_NNS of_IN housing_NN for_IN animals_NNS ._.
In_IN comparing_VBG the_DT different_JJ groups_NNS of_IN animals_NNS used_VBN in_IN this_DT experiment_NN ,_, the_DT Egyptian_JJ cattle_NN was_VBD found_VBN to_TO be_VB very_RB stable_JJ in_IN its_PRP$ reactions_NNS to_TO the_DT different_JJ treat-_JJ ments_NNS ._.
This_DT ,_, added_VBD to_TO its_PRP$ ability_NN to_TO withstand_VB exposure_NN to_TO sun_VB [_JJ Asker_NNP ,_, et_FW al._NN ,_, 1952_CD ]_NN ,_, denotes_VBZ to_TO its_PRP$ profound_NN suitability_NN for_IN the_DT environmental_JJ conditions_NNS in_IN this_DT country_NN ._.
The_DT buffaloes_NNS and_CC pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP were_VBD the_DT most_RBS sensitive_JJ to_TO the_DT effect_NN of_IN exposure_NN to_TO sun_VB ;_: here_RB they_PRP also_RB proved_VBD to_TO be_VB the_DT most_RBS sensitive_JJ in_IN their_PRP$ reactions_NNS to_TO shade_VB and_CC sprinkling_VBG ,_, since_IN their_PRP$ temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN decreased_VBD more_RBR rapidly_RB ._.
5AR/53_CD 214_CD EFFECT_NN OF_NNP SHADING_NNP AND_NNP SPRINKLING_NNP [_NNP Vol_NNP ._.
XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, The_DT quick_JJ response_NN of_IN buffaloes_NNS and_CC pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP to_TO shade_VB is_VBZ difficult_JJ to_TO explain_VB ._.
As_RB far_RB as_IN farm_NN work_NN is_VBZ concerned_VBN ,_, the_DT Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS should_MD be_VB the_DT only_JJ depend-_JJ able_JJ animals_NNS in_IN this_DT respect_NN especially_RB in_IN summer_NN time_NN ,_, since_IN work_NN means_NNS ,_, in_IN other_JJ words_NNS ,_, exposure_NN to_TO sun_VB ._.
SUMMARY_NNP The_DT effect_NN of_IN shading_VBG outdoor_NN ,_, shading_VBG indoor_NN ,_, either_RB preceded_VBN by_IN sprinkling_VBG for_IN 3_CD and_CC 5_CD minutes_NNS or_CC not_RB ,_, were_VBD investigated_VBN as_IN means_NNS of_IN keeping_VBG down_RP the_DT body_NN temperature_NN ,_, and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN of_IN buffaloes_NNS ,_, Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS ,_, pure_NN Jerseys_NNP and_CC pure_NN and_CC graded_VBD Shorthorns_NNP during_IN the_DT summer_NN season_NN ._.
The_DT results_NNS obtained_VBD could_MD be_VB summarized_VBN in_IN the_DT following_NN :_: 1_CD ._.
Body_NN temperature_NN ,_, after_IN shading_VBG for_IN one_CD hour_NN outdoor_NN ,_, was_VBD reduced_VBN by_IN 1.3_CD per_IN cent_NN ,_, 0.25_CD per_IN cent_NN and_CC 1.3_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN buffaloes_NNS ,_, native_JJ cattle_NNS and_CC pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP respectively_RB ._.
After_IN two_CD hours_NNS of_IN shading_NN ,_, the_DT decrease_NN in_IN body_NN tem-_JJ perature_NN amounted_VBD to_TO 1.8_CD per_IN cent_NN for_IN the_DT buffaloes_NNS and_CC 0.52_CD per_IN cent_NN in_IN Egyptian_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
The_DT Shorthorns_NNP did_VBD not_RB show_VB any_DT further_JJ sign_NN of_IN decline_NN in_IN this_DT respect_NN ._.
Respiration_NN rate_NN followed_VBD the_DT same_JJ trend_NN in_IN general_JJ but_CC the_DT rate_NN of_IN decline_NN was_VBD different_JJ in_IN its_PRP$ percentage_NN ._.
The_DT pulse_NN rate_NN was_VBD not_RB similar_JJ for_IN any_DT of_IN the_DT two_CD readings_NNS previously_RB discussed_VBN ._.
2_CD ._.
The_DT animals_NNS after_IN shading_VBG indoor_NN for_IN one_CD hour_NN ranked_VBN in_IN their_PRP$ rate_NN of_IN de-_JJ crease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN as_IN follows_VBZ :_: Pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP ,_, buffaloes_NNS ,_, pure_NN Jerseys_NNP ,_, Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS and_CC native_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
As_RB far_RB as_IN their_PRP$ respiration_NN rate_NN is_VBZ concerned_VBN ,_, the_DT rate_NN of_IN decrease_NN was_VBD highest_JJS in_IN buffaloes_NNS being_VBG 50.8_CD per_IN cent_NN ,_, followed_VBN by_IN pure_NN Shorthorns_NNP and_CC Shorthorn_NNP grades_NNS (_( both_DT 38.3_CD per_IN cent_NN )_) then_RB the_DT pure_NN Jerseys_NNP (_( 33.8_CD per_IN cent_NN )_) and_CC comes_VBZ last_JJ the_DT native_JJ cattle_NNS being_VBG 31.6_CD per_IN cent_NN ._.
After_IN two_CD hours_NNS both_DT body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN continued_VBD to_TO decrease_VB in_IN all_DT animals_NNS except_IN native_JJ cattle_NNS ._.
3_CD ._.
Sprinkling_VBG for_IN three_CD minutes_NNS followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG indoors_NNS for_IN one_CD hour_NN was_VBD more_RBR effective_JJ in_IN keeping_VBG down_RP body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN than_IN shading_VBG only_RB ._.
4_CD ._.
Sprinkling_VBG for_IN three_CD minutes_NNS followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG outdoors_NNS for_IN two_CD hours_NNS caused_VBD a_DT decrease_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN ,_, respiration_NN and_CC pulse_NN rates_NNS after_IN one_CD hour_NN in_IN all_DT animals_NNS in_IN general_JJ ._.
Their_PRP$ reaction_NN after_IN two_CD hours_NNS was_VBD different_JJ ._.
5_CD ._.
Sprinkling_VBG for_IN five_CD minutes_NNS followed_VBN by_IN shading_VBG outdoor_NN for_IN one_CD hour_NN caused_VBD a_DT decline_NN in_IN body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN in_IN all_DT animals_NNS ._.
The_DT difference_NN in_IN time_NN between_IN this_DT treatment_NN and_CC that_IN of_IN three_CD minutes_NNS did_VBD not_RB seem_VB to_TO have_VB a_DT more_RBR appreciable_JJ effect_NN on_IN body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN ._.
6_CD ._.
In_IN all_DT treatments_NNS ,_, the_DT pulse_NN rate_NN was_VBD affected_VBN ,_, but_CC it_PRP had_VBD no_DT special_JJ trend_NN as_IN it_PRP was_VBD noticed_VBN for_IN both_DT body_NN temperature_NN and_CC respiration_NN rate_NN ._.

6_CD 258-264_JJ ABSTRACTS_NNP Interim_NNP report_NN on_IN research_NN on_IN foot_NN and_CC mouth_NN disease_NN at_IN the_DT Research_NNP Institute_NNP ,_, Pirbright_NNP Surrey_NNP (_( 1952_CD )_) ._.

108_CD ,_, 359-367_JJ INTERIM_NNP report_NN of_IN work_NN done_VBN on_IN foot_NN and_CC mouth_NN disease_NN at_IN Pirbright_NNP for_IN the_DT last_JJ 12_CD years_NNS had_VBD brought_VBN a_DT number_NN of_IN interesting_JJ facts_NNS to_TO light_NN ._.
It_PRP has_VBZ been_VBN found_VBN that_IN pigs_NNS are_VBP more_RBR susceptible_JJ than_IN cattle_NNS and_CC that_IN there_EX is_VBZ species_NNS specificity_NN ;_: pig_NN 's_POS strain_NN will_MD spread_VB more_RBR quickly_RB in_IN pigs_NNS than_IN in_IN cattle_NNS and_CC vice_NN versa_NN ._.
Different_JJ strains_NNS of_IN virus_NN within_IN each_DT type_NN ,_, differ_NN in_IN severity_NN of_IN the_DT disease_NN they_PRP cause_VBP and_CC the_DT ease_NN with_IN which_WDT they_PRP spread_VBP ._.
Three_CD new_JJ types_NNS from_IN outbreaks_NNS in_IN S._NNP Africa_NNP have_VBP been_VBN identified_VBN ._.
Virus_NNP has_VBZ been_VBN found_VBN to_TO consist_VB of_IN two_CD components_NNS ,_, the_DT larger_JJR gives_VBZ a_DT positive_JJ complement_NN fixation_NN test_NN and_CC is_VBZ infective_JJ ,_, and_CC the_DT smaller_JJR is_VBZ positive_JJ to_TO complement_VB fixation_NN test_NN ,_, but_CC non-infective_JJ ._.
Complement_JJ fixation_NN test_NN has_VBZ been_VBN further_RB developed_VBN to_TO determine_VB the_DT strain_NN of_IN virus_NN and_CC this_DT can_MD be_VB done_VBN within_IN a_DT few_JJ hours_NNS of_IN the_DT receipt_NN of_IN material_NN from_IN a_DT suspected_JJ outbreak_NN ._.
This_DT test_NN is_VBZ also_RB used_VBN for_IN differential_JJ diagnosis_NN ,_, against_IN diseases_NNS like_IN vesicular_JJ stomatitis_NN ._.
Vaccine_NNP has_VBZ been_VBN prepared_VBN by_IN cultivating_VBG virus_NN in_IN the_DT tongue_NN of_IN animals_NNS slaugh-_JJ tered_VBD for_IN food_NN ._.
These_DT vaccines_NNS have_VBP been_VBN found_VBN as_RB useful_JJ as_IN the_DT ones_NNS prepared_VBN in_IN live_JJ cattle_NNS which_WDT are_VBP much_RB more_RBR expensive_JJ ._.
It_PRP has_VBZ been_VBN found_VBN possible_JJ to_TO infect_VB unweaned_JJ mice_NN ,_, and_CC this_DT suggests_VBZ another_DT source_NN of_IN cultivating_VBG virus_NN for_IN vaccine_NN production_NN ._.
Immunity_NN lasts_VBZ for_IN four_CD months_NNS only_RB ._.
It_PRP has_VBZ been_VBN shown_VBN that_IN all_DT body_NN tissues_NNS of_IN infected_JJ carcasses_NNS are_VBP capable_JJ of_IN transmitting_VBG infection_NN ._.
Quick_NNP frozen_JJ meat_NN and_CC its_PRP$ wrappings_NNS were_VBD found_VBN to_TO be_VB more_RBR dangerous_JJ than_IN meat_NN frozen_VBN by_IN ordinary_JJ methods_NNS or_CC chilled_VBN ._.

FORD_NNP ,_, E._NNP T._NNP H._NNP (_( 1952_CD )_) ._.
Brit_NNP ._.

108_CD ,_, 411-418_JJ SIX_NNP cases_NNS of_IN Johne_NNP 's_POS disease_NN in_IN cattle_NNS were_VBD treated_VBN ,_, three_CD with_IN T._NNP B._NNP I_PRP and_CC three_CD with_IN streptomycin_NN ._.
No_DT cures_NNS were_VBD obtained_VBN ,_, but_CC in_IN one_CD case_NN Mycobacterium_NNP johnei_NN failed_VBD to_TO grow_VB from_IN intestines_NNS and_CC mesenteric_JJ glands_NNS at_IN post_NN mortem_NN ._.
(_( Author_NN 's_POS own_JJ summary_NN ._. )_)
[_NN H._NNP K._NNP L._NNP ]_NNP The_DT sheep_JJ dog218_NN ABSTRACT_NNP Vol_NNP ._.
XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP III_NNP ,_, unbalanced_VBD ._.
During_IN the_DT lambing_NN season_NN ,_, when_WRB hill_NN farmer_NN has_VBZ to_TO walk_VB about_IN 25_CD miles_NNS a_DT day_NN ,_, sheep_JJ dog_NN may_MD have_VB to_TO do_VB as_RB much_RB as_IN 90_CD to_TO 100_CD miles_NNS a_DT day_NN ._.
Most_JJS of_IN these_DT sheep_JJ dogs_NNS belong_RB to_TO the_DT Border_NNP Collic_NNP type_NN weighing_VBG about_RB 30_CD to_TO 50_CD lb_NN ._.
and_CC measuring_VBG about_RB 18_CD to_TO 22_CD inches_NNS at_IN shoulder_NN height_NN ._.
The_DT common_JJ daily_JJ ration_NN of_IN sheep_JJ dog_NN consisted_VBD of_IN a_DT mixture_NN of_IN ½_NNP lb_NN ._.
maize_VB meal_NN ,_, ½_NNP lb_NN ._.
oat_NN meal_NN and_CC ½_JJ pint_NN of_IN milk_NN ,_, in_IN addition_NN to_TO table_VB scrap_NN ,_, occasionally_RB rabbit_NN or_CC horse_NN flesh_NN and_CC sheep_JJ placentia_NN during_IN the_DT lambing_NN season_NN ._.
Analytical_NNP study_NN of_IN this_DT diet_JJ found_VBD it_PRP to_TO be_VB deficient_JJ in_IN calcium_NN ,_, nicotinic_JJ acid_NN and_CC possibly_RB in_IN riboflarin_NN and_CC vitamin_NN D._NNP All_NNP these_DT defi-_JJ ciencies_NNS ,_, if_IN made_VBN up_RP ,_, would_MD naturally_RB lead_VB to_TO general_JJ improvement_NN of_IN the_DT sheep_JJ dog_NN 's_POS health_NN ._.
In_IN author_NN 's_POS opinion_NN ,_, the_DT high_JJ standard_NN of_IN health_NN generally_RB attributed_VBN to_TO the_DT sheep_JJ dog_NN ,_, was_VBD more_RBR apparent_JJ than_IN real_JJ ._.
The_DT active_JJ working_JJ life_NN of_IN a_DT hill_NN collie_NN while_IN intense_JJ ,_, was_VBD of_IN relatively_RB short_JJ duration_NN and_CC the_DT arduous_JJ and_CC exacting_VBG work_NN performed_VBN was_VBD a_DT reflection_NN of_IN his_PRP$ inherent_JJ devotion_NN to_TO duty_NN rather_RB than_IN of_IN a_DT high_JJ level_NN of_IN robust_JJ health_NN ._.

103_CD ,_, 12_CD KABETE_NNP strain_NN of_IN rinderpest_NN virus_NN and_CC a_DT field_NN strain_NN of_IN virus_NN ,_, produced_VBD incon-_JJ sistent_JJ temperature_NN reaction_NN in_IN indigenous_JJ fat-tailed_JJ hairy_NN sheep_NN and_CC temporary_JJ viraemia_NN ._.

[_NN H._NNP K._NNP L._NNP ]_NNP REVIEW_NNP HOME_NNP DOCTORING_NNP OF_NNP ANIMALS_NNP BY_NNP HAROLD_NNP LEENEY_NNP (_( Revised_VBN by_IN C._NNP G._NNP Saunders_NNP )_) (_( Published_VBN by_IN '_POS Farm_NN and_CC Stock-Breeder_NNP '_'' ,_, London_NNP ,_, 1952_CD )_) THIS_NNP is_VBZ the_DT fifth_JJ edition_NN of_IN a_DT popular_JJ book_NN ,_, largely_RB rewritten_JJ and_CC brought_VBD up-to-_JJ date_NN by_IN Saunders_NNP ._.

(_( H._NNP D._NNP S._NNP )_) 219_CD MGIPCORIGINAL_NNP ARTICLES_NNP STUDIES_NNP ON_NNP CALCIUM_NNP AND_NNP PHOSPHORUS_NNP IN_NNP MILK_NNP AND_NNP FEEDS_NNP OF_NNP SAHIWAL_NNP COWS_NNP FROM_NNP PRECALVING_NNP PERIOD_NNP TO_NNP THE_NNP END_NNP OF_NNP LACTATION_NNP By_IN M._NNP L._NNP Mathur_NNP and_CC S._NNP V._NNP Desai_NNP ,_, Indian_JJ Agricultural_NNP Research_NNP Institute_NNP ,_, New_NNP Delhi_NNP (_( Received_VBN for_IN publication_NN on_IN 6_CD April_NNP 1951*_CD )_) (_( With_IN 13_CD text-figures_NNS )_) IN_NNP our_PRP$ previous_JJ publication_NN [_NN 1945_CD ]_NN ,_, we_PRP had_VBD pointed_VBN out_RP the_DT trend_NN of_IN calcium_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN contents_NNS of_IN pre-milk_NN and_CC milk_NN after_IN lactation_NN in_IN Sahiwal_NNP cows_NNS ._.

The_DT object_NN was_VBD to_TO study_VB if_IN there_EX were_VBD and_CC if_IN so_RB to_TO what_WP extent_NN ,_, variation_NN in_IN the_DT percentage_NN ,_, ratio_NN and_CC total_JJ outgo_NN of_IN calcium_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN in_IN relation_NN to_TO the_DT yield_NN of_IN milk_NN ,_, age_NN and_CC stage_NN of_IN lactation_NN ._.

XXIII_NN ,_, Part_NNP IV_NNP ,_, Graphs_NNP for_IN each_DT cow_NN ,_, showing_VBG curves_NNS for_IN CaO_NNP and_CC P2O5_NNP per_IN cent_NN in_IN milk_NN ,_, calcium_NN phosphorus_NN ratio_NN ,_, total_JJ calcium_NN oxide_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN pentoxide_NN in_IN the_DT milk_NN and_CC the_DT daily_JJ milk_NN yield_NN during_IN the_DT precalving_JJ period_NN and_CC throughout_IN the_DT lactation_NN are_VBP shown_VBN in_IN Fig_NNP ._.
1_CD to_TO 13_CD ._.
DISCUSSION_NN OF_IN THE_NNP RESULTS_NNP Calcium_NNP percentage_NN of_IN milk_NN The_DT percentage_NN of_IN Calcium_NNP was_VBD very_RB low_JJ about_IN 0.02_CD to_TO 0.11_CD per_IN cent_NN on_IN the_DT first_JJ day_NN of_IN taking_VBG out_RP pre-milk_NN and_CC tended_VBD to_TO increase_VB as_IN the_DT time_NN of_IN calving_VBG approached_VBN and_CC continued_VBN to_TO increase_VB for_IN a_DT week_NN or_CC two_CD after_IN calving_VBG ._.
As_IN the_DT milk_NN yield_NN increased_VBD with_IN the_DT approach_NN of_IN flush_JJ period_NN the_DT percentage_NN of_IN calcium_NN fell_VBD ._.
It_PRP remained_VBD at_IN low_JJ level_NN for_IN some_DT time_NN and_CC then_RB the_DT tendency_NN was_VBD to_TO increase_VB and_CC remain_VB more_JJR or_CC less_RBR constant_JJ for_IN a_DT fairly_RB long_JJ period_NN of_IN lactation_NN ._.
It_PRP then_RB again_RB increased_VBN with_IN the_DT start_NN of_IN gestation_NN period_NN and_CC shrinkage_NN in_IN the_DT milk_NN yield_NN ._.
Phosphorus_NNP percentage_NN of_IN milk_NN The_DT percentage_NN of_IN phosphorus_NN was_VBD fairly_RB high_JJ about_IN 0.1_CD to_TO 0.3_CD per_IN cent_NN in_IN the_DT pre-milk_NN on_IN the_DT first_JJ day_NN of_IN pre-milking_NN and_CC continued_VBD to_TO increase_VB ,_, reaching_VBG the_DT maximum_NN (_( 0.30_CD to_TO 0.37_CD per_IN cent_NN )_) a_DT day_NN or_CC two_CD before_IN calving_VBG (_( in_IN few_JJ cases_NNS after_IN also_RB )_) and_CC then_RB decreased_VBD ._.
The_DT tendency_NN to_TO decrease_VB continued_VBN for_IN about_RB two_CD weeks_NNS ._.
It_PRP remained_VBD at_IN low_JJ level_NN for_IN some_DT time_NN and_CC then_RB tended_VBD to_TO increase_VB and_CC remain_VB more_JJR or_CC less_RBR constant_JJ and_CC the_DT tendency_NN was_VBD to_TO run_VB parallel_RB to_TO calcium_VB curve_NN ._.
Calcium_NN :_: Phosphorus_NNP ratio_NN in_IN milk_NN The_DT CaO_NNP :_: P2O5_NNP ratio_NN was_VBD high_JJ (_( 1.20_CD to_TO 4.0_CD )_) and_CC fluctuating_VBG in_IN the_DT pre-milk_NN ._.
After_IN calving_VBG ,_, there_EX was_VBD sharp_JJ fall_NN in_IN the_DT ratio_NN ._.
It_PRP remained_VBD low_JJ during_IN the_DT flush_JJ period_NN and_CC then_RB increased_VBD slightly_RB and_CC remained_VBD more_RBR or_CC less_RBR constant_JJ throughout_IN the_DT lactation_NN period_NN ._.
Calcium_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN in_IN the_DT milk_NN The_DT curves_NNS for_IN total_JJ calcium_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN in_IN milk_NN run_VBN more_RBR or_CC less_JJR parallel_NNS ._.
Since_IN the_DT CaO_NNP and_CC P2O5_NNP contents_NNS of_IN the_DT milk_NN depend_VBP more_JJR on_IN the_DT yield_NN of_IN milk_NN than_IN on_IN the_DT CaO_NNP and_CC P2O5_NNP per_IN cent_NN ,_, they_PRP are_VBP similar_JJ and_CC run_VB parallel_RB to_TO the_DT curves_NNS of_IN milk_NN yield_NN ._.
While_IN the_DT trend_NN of_IN the_DT curves_NNS of_IN CaO_NNP and_CC P2O5_NNP per_IN cent_NN is_VBZ to_TO go_VB up_RP ,_, the_DT curves_NNS for_IN total_JJ CaO_NNP and_CC P2O5_NNP in_IN milk_NN is_VBZ slanting_VBG upward_RB ._.
Milk_NNP yield_VBP The_DT curves_NNS for_IN the_DT milk_NN yields_NNS have_VBP been_VBN shown_VBN for_IN each_DT cow_NN ._.
After_IN calving_VBG ,_, there_EX is_VBZ a_DT sharp_JJ rise_NN in_IN the_DT curves_NNS ._.
The_DT milk_NN yield_NN remains_VBZ at_IN that_DT level_NN for_IN 8_CD to_TO 18_CD weeks_NNS and_CC then_RB the_DT shrinkage_NN is_VBZ visible_JJ by_IN the_DT slanting_VBG down_IN of_IN the_DT curves_NNS ._.
Table_JJ III_NNP shows_VBZ the_DT average_JJ milk_NN yield_NN ,_, CaO_NNP and_CC P2O5_NNP per_IN cent_NN ,_, total_JJ calcium_NN oxide_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN pentoxide_NN in_IN milk_NN in_IN the_DT (_( i_NN )_) pre_NN calving_VBG period_NN (_( ii_JJ )_) before_IN flush_JJ period_NN (_( iii_JJ )_) during_IN flush_JJ period_NN and_CC (_( iv_NN )_) after_IN flush_NN in_IN case_NN of_IN high_JJ ,_, medium_NN and_CC low_JJ milking_NN cows_NNS ._.

Before_IN flush_JJ 20.7_CD 0.174_CD 16.38_CD 0.273_CD 25.24_CD 1_CD :_: 1.58_CD 3_CD ._.
During_IN flush_JJ 22.0_CD 0.171_CD 17.13_CD 0.215_CD 21.51_CD 1_CD :_: 1.26_CD 4_CD ._.
After_IN flush_JJ 12.4_CD 0.181_CD 10.13_CD 0.227_CD 12.73_CD 1_CD :_: 1.25_CD It_PRP appears_VBZ that_IN calcium_NN and_CC phosphorus_NN contents_NNS in_IN the_DT milk_NN in_IN different_JJ groups_NNS of_IN cows_NNS are_VBP about_IN the_DT same_JJ ._.

or_CC more_JJR per_IN day_NN ,_, on_IN a_DT good_JJ feed_NN ,_, but_CC not_RB supplemented_VBN by_IN mineral_JJ salts_NNS ._.

respectively_RB ._.

The_DT necessity_NN of_IN feeding_VBG mineral_JJ supplement_NN is_VBZ therefore_RB felt_VBN for_IN a_DT small_JJ period_NN in_IN low_JJ milkers_NNS ,_, greater_JJR period_NN in_IN medium_NN milkers_NNS and_CC almost_RB throughout_IN the_DT lacta-_JJ tion_NN period_NN in_IN the_DT case_NN of_IN high_JJ milkers_NNS ._.

in_IN the_DT milk_NN yield_NN ._.
In_IN our_PRP$ experiments_NNS [_VB 1953_CD ]_IN we_PRP found_VBD that_IN CaO_NNP :_: P2O5_NNP ratio_VBP varying_VBG from_IN 1.0_CD to_TO 2.0_CD maintained_VBN positive_JJ calcium_NN balance_NN but_CC not_RB phosphorus_JJ balance_NN ._.
The_DT phosphorus_NN assimilation_NN was_VBD larger_JJR in_IN high_JJ phosphorus_NN period_NN when_WRB the_DT CaO_NNP :_: P2O5_NNP ratio_NN was_VBD about_RB 1.0_CD to_TO 1.25_CD ._.
Keeping_VBG these_DT into_IN consideration_NN ,_, the_DT mineral_JJ mixture_NN should_MD be_VB such_JJ as_IN to_TO provide_VB an_DT optimum_JJ CaO_NN :_: P2O5_NNP ratio_NN in_IN the_DT feed_NN ._.
A_DT mineral_JJ mixture_NN of_IN the_DT following_JJ composition_NN is_VBZ considered_VBN very_RB suitable_JJ ._.
Sterilized_VBN bone-meal_JJ 50_CD lb_NN ._.
Finely_RB ground_NN chalk_NN 15_CD lb_NN ._.
Di-calcium_JJ phosphate_NN 10_CD lb_NN ._.
Sulphur_NNP 3_CD lb_NN ._.
Common_JJ salt_NN (_( NaCl_NNP )_) 20_CD lb_NN ._.

Potassium_NNP iodide_RB 4_CD oz_NN ._.
Finely_RB ground_NN anhydrous_JJ copper_NN sulphate_NN 0.5_CD oz_NN ._.
Finely_RB ground_NN cobalt_VBD chloride_RB 0.1_CD oz_NN ._.
Manganese_JJ sulphate_NN 4_CD oz_NN ._.
